CaseName: Leathers, Commissioner Of Revenues Of Arkansas V. Medlock Et Al.
CaseSummary: State sales tax which excluded certain segments of media did not violate First Amendment because the tax was not directed at and did not present the danger of suppressing particular ideas.

CaseName: Jill S. Kamen V. Kemper Financial Services, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because the futility of demand in a derivative suit brought on behalf of an investment company against its investment adviser was a substantive issue governed by state law, no rule of "universal demand" could be adopted as federal common law.

CaseName: Frederick A. Siegert V. H. Melvin Gilley
CaseSummary: Because federal employee's defamation complaint did not state claim for violation of any rights secured to him under U.S. Constitution, dismissal of action was affirmed, and it was not necessary to reach issue of his supervisor's qualified immunity.

CaseName: Jeanne Farrey, Fka Jeanne Sanderfoot V. Gerald J. Sanderfoot
CaseSummary: A state homestead exemption in bankruptcy could not be used to avoid a lien created by a divorce decree on the marital home because the parties' interests in the marital home attached at the same time as the lien against the property.

CaseName: Curtis Reed Johnson V. Home State Bank
CaseSummary: Debtor, whose personal liability to mortgagee was discharged in Chapter 7 bankruptcy, was allowed to include in rem judgment that mortgagee obtained against debtor's property as a claim in a Chapter 13 plan as creditor's claim survived the discharge.

CaseName: Sheldon Baruch Toibb V. Stuart J. Radloff
CaseSummary: An individual not engaged in a business was eligible for Chapter 11 bankruptcy because the plain language of the Bankruptcy Code allows individuals and businesses to reorganize under Chapter 11.

CaseName: Lampf, Pleva, Lipkind, Prupis & Petigrow V. John Gilbertson, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Federal law was appropriate to use in determining the statute of limitations for federal securities violation claims, and since the applicable federal regulations did not allow for equitable tolling of the claims, they were time barred.

CaseName: Michael Barnes, Prosecuting Attorney Of St. Joseph County, Indiana, Et Al. V. Glen Theatre, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Judgment that nude dancing was expression protected by First Amendment reversed, since public nudity was sufficiently important government interest to justify regulating non-speech element of the expressive conduct.

CaseName: Cohen V. Cowles Media Co., Dba Minneapolis Star & Tribune Co., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Informer was entitled to compensatory damages after publisher breached its confidentiality agreement, because publisher was liable based on promissory estoppel. First Amendment gave publisher no special immunity from application of general laws.

CaseName: Southwest Marine, Inc. V. Byron Gizoni
CaseSummary: The Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act (Act) did not provide the exclusive remedy for all harbor workers, and workers receiving voluntary payment under the Act without a formal award were not barred from pursuing Jones Act relief.

CaseName: Simon & Schuster, Inc. V. Members Of The New York State Crime Victims Board, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Petitioner's challenge to the constitutionality of an amendment to New York's Son of Sam law was successful because the Court concluded that the law imposed a financial disincentive to create or publish works with a particular content.

CaseName: Union Bank V. Herbert Wolas, Chapter 7 Trustee For The Estate Of Zzzz Best Co., Inc.
CaseSummary: A debtor's payments on long-term debt could qualify for the ordinary course of business exception, as provided in the Bankruptcy Code, to the trustee's power to avoid preferential transfers.

CaseName: Kenneth Hilton V. South Carolina Public Railways Commission
CaseSummary: The Supreme Court reaffirmed a decision holding that the Federal Employers' Liability Act authorized suit for damages against state-owned railroads and that by entering the railroad business a state waived its Eleventh Amendment immunity.

CaseName: Shirley M. Molzof, Personal Representative Of The Estate Of Robert E. Molzof V. United States
CaseSummary: The Federal Tort Claims Act's prohibition against punitive damage awards did not prohibit a survivor from recovering damages for the cost of medical care that was provided free of charge at a veterans' hospital or for loss of enjoyment of life.

CaseName: Aletha Dewsnup V. Louis L. Timm, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A debtor's suit to "strip down" creditors' lien on the debtor's real property to equal the property's fair market value and declare the remainder void was dismissed because the creditors' claim had been "allowed" and was "secured."

CaseName: United States V. Nordic Village Inc., David O. Simon, Trustee
CaseSummary: Where there was no statutory basis to establish an unequivocal textual waiver of the government's immunity from a bankruptcy trustee's claim for monetary relief, reversal of a lower court's decision granting such recovery was warranted.

CaseName: Christine Franklin V. Gwinnett County Public Schools And William Prescott.
CaseSummary: A student was entitled to a damages remedy for an action brought to enforce Title IX.

CaseName: Arkansas, Et Al. V. Oklahoma, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Denial of discharge permit to Arkansas was improper because Clean Water Act preempted an action based on the law of the affected State and the only law applicable to an interstate discharge was the law of the State in which point source was located.

CaseName: David Dawson V. Delaware
CaseSummary: Admission into evidence of defendant's membership in the Aryan Brotherhood, a racist prison gang, at the penalty phase of murder trial was totally without relevance and was constitutional error; evidence was not tied in any way to murder victim.

CaseName: General Motors Corporation, Et Al. V. Evert Romein Et Al.
CaseSummary: The retroactive application of a statute requiring employers, who had impermissibly withheld workers' compensation benefits from disabled employees, to refund such payments did not violate the Contracts Clause or the Due Process Clause.

CaseName: Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Et Al. V. Robert T. Darden
CaseSummary: To determine whether an insurance agent was an employee of an insurance company for the purpose of obtaining retirement benefits under ERISA, the correct test of employee status was the master-servant relationship under the common law of agency.

CaseName: William Barnhill V. Elliot Johnson, Trustee
CaseSummary: Where debtor delivered check to creditor outside 90-day preference period but check was honored within preference period, bankruptcy trustee was properly permitted to avoid payment as preference as transfer took place on date check was honored.

CaseName: F. Dale Robertson, Chief, United States Forest Service, Et. Al. V. Seattle Audubon Society Et Al.
CaseSummary: A federal statute was improperly held unconstitutional because the statute, in replacing a legal standard for pending litigation, did not compel courts to make particular findings of fact, applications of law to fact, nor render specific results.

CaseName: United States Department Of Energy V. Ohio, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Clean Water Act and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 unambiguously waived sovereign immunity from civil penalties against the U.S., but the waiver went no further than the coercive variety and did not extend to punitive fines.

CaseName: Robert J. Taylor, Trustee V. Freeland & Kronz, Wendell G. Freeland And Richard F. Kronz
CaseSummary: A bankruptcy debtor's trustee was properly barred from challenging the validity of an exemption because the trustee failed to timely object to the exemption, even though the debtor had no colorable statutory basis for claiming the exemption.

CaseName: Charles W. Burson, Attorney General And Reporter For Tennessee V. Mary Rebecca Freeman
CaseSummary: Following strict scrutiny, state statute imposing 100-foot boundary restriction on distribution of campaign materials on election day found constitutional; statute constituted compromise between competing fundamental rights.

CaseName: John H. Evans, Jr. V. United States
CaseSummary: Nothing in text or legislative history of Hobbs Act was contrary to common-law meaning of extortion, so Government needed only to show that public official obtained payment to which he was not entitled, knowing it was made in return for official act.

CaseName: Quill Corporation V. North Dakota By And Through Its Tax Commissioner, Heidi Heitkamp
CaseSummary: A North Dakota use tax upon an out-of-state mail order house violated the negative implication of the Commerce Clause, which prohibited state taxation on interstate commerce.

CaseName: Chemical Waste Management, Inc. V. Guy Hunt, Governor Of Alabama Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state statute that imposed a hazardous waste disposal fee on hazardous wastes generated outside the state and disposed of in the state violated the commerce clause because the fee did not apply to waste generated in the state.

CaseName: Fort Gratiot Sanitary Landfill, Inc. V. Michigan Department Of Natural Resources Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state statute that prohibited private landfill operators from accepting solid waste originating outside the county where the landfill operators were located was held to be unconstitutional as a violation of the Commerce Clause.

CaseName: Eastman Kodak Company V. Image Technical Services, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: In an antitrust suit, the court affirmed the reversal of grant of summary judgment, finding that competition in the equipment market would necessarily prevent a film company from engaging in a tying arrangement in the service and parts markets.

CaseName: Federal Trade Commission V. Ticor Title Insurance Company, Et Al.
CaseSummary: As state did not actively supervise conduct, the court reversed judgment holding that respondent title insurance companies were entitled to state action immunity for FTC Act violation for horizontal price fixing by use of state rating bureaus.

CaseName: John R. Patterson, Trustee V. Joseph B. Shumate, Jr.
CaseSummary: ERISA-qualified plans constitute "applicable nonbankruptcy law" and contain enforceable restrictions on the transfer of pension interests. A debtor's interest in such a pension plan may be excluded from the property of the bankruptcy estate.

CaseName: Allied-signal, Inc., As Successor-in-interest To The Bendix Corporation V. Director, Division Of Taxation
CaseSummary: A corporate taxpayer earning multistate income did not have to pay an apportioned share of income tax to the state of New Jersey when it realized gain from the sale of stock in a New York company, which was not part of its unitary business.

CaseName: Stephanie Nordlinger V. Kenneth Hahn, In His Capacity As Tax Assessor For Los Angeles County, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state law providing for strict limits on real property taxes and assessments rationally furthered legitimate purposes, and exemptions that resulted in unequal assessments did not violate federal constitutional law.

CaseName: Kraft General Foods, Inc. V. Iowa Department Of Revenue And Finance
CaseSummary: An Iowa statute taxing a corporation's foreign subsidiaries but not its domestic subsidiaries discriminated, on its face, against foreign commerce because it advocated domestic commerce over foreign commerce.

CaseName: Mary Gade, Director, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency V. National Solid Wastes Management Association
CaseSummary: Illinois' licensing laws regarding workers' handling of hazardous waste were preempted by the Occupational Safety and Health Act even though the state agency's environmental regulation had the dual purpose of protecting both the public and workers.

CaseName: Forsyth County, Georgia V. The Nationalist Movement
CaseSummary: A county ordinance was determined to be invalid because it unconstitutionally tied the amount of the fee charged for parading and assembling to the content of the speech without providing adequate procedural safeguards.

CaseName: Wisconsin Department Of Revenue V. William Wrigley, Jr., Co.
CaseSummary: Since the company's business activities within Wisconsin were not limited to those specified in the federal franchise tax statute, the prohibition on net-income taxation contained in the provision was inapplicable.

CaseName: Rav V. City Of St. Paul, Minnesota
CaseSummary: A local bias-motivated crime ordinance was struck down as facially unconstitutional under the First Amendment because it imposed special prohibitions on speakers expressing views on disfavored subjects.

CaseName: Estate Of Floyd Cowart V. Nicklos Drilling Company, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where the injured employee, without the employer's consent, settled with a third party for an amount less than the worker was entitled to under the Longshore and Harbor Workers Compensation Act, he forfeited future benefits under the Act.

CaseName: Robert E. Lee, Individually And As Principal Of Nathan Bishop Middle School, Et Al. V. Daniel Weisman Etc.
CaseSummary: The inclusion of clerical members who offered prayers as part of official public school graduation ceremonies was inconsistent with the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment of the Constitution.

CaseName: International Society For Krishna Consciousness, Inc., And Brian Rumbaugh V. Walter Lee
CaseSummary: Denial of religious group's declaratory relief petition affirmed because an airport was not a traditional public forum for the free expression of ideas and a regulation limiting speech was reasonable to promote crowd control.

CaseName: Two Pesos, Inc. V. Taco Cabana, Inc.
CaseSummary: A judgment upholding a jury verdict for respondent restaurant in its Lanham Act suit for trade dress infringement was affirmed, as proof of secondary meaning was not required to prevail where respondent's trade dress was inherently distinctive.

CaseName: Walter Lee, Superintendent Of Port Authority Police V. International Society For Krishna Consciousness, Inc., Et Al.
Planned Parenthood Of Southeastern Pennsylvania, Et Al. V. Robert P. Casey, Et Al., Etc.
CaseSummary: The Court held that the husband notification provision of the Pennsylvania Abortion Control Act placed an undue burden on a woman's right to have an abortion in a large fraction of cases and was unconstitutional.

CaseName: Bath Iron Works Corporation, Et Al. V. Director, Office Of Workers' Compensation Programs, Etc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A claimant who discovered a work related hearing loss should properly have been compensated for a scheduled injury despite the fact that he was retired.

CaseName: Spectrum Sports, Inc., Et Al. V. Shirley Mcquillan, Et Vir, Dba Sorboturf Enterprises
CaseSummary: An attempted monopolization judgment against a polymer corporation was reversed absent proof that the corporation intended to monopolize or that there was a dangerous probability of monopolization in a relevant market.

CaseName: Itel Containers International Corporation V. Joe Huddleston, Commissioner Of Revenue Of Tennessee
CaseSummary: State sales tax on leases for containers used in international shipping did not violate international conventions signed by the United States, as it taxed the transfer of title or possession and did not discriminate against imported products.

CaseName: Bob Reves, Et Al. V. Ernst & Young
CaseSummary: An outside accounting firm was not liable to a class of note holders for a RICO violation when there was insufficient evidence that it had participated in the operation or management of the enterprise itself.

CaseName: Sandra Jean Smith V. United States
CaseSummary: The dismissal a widow's wrongful death complaint based exclusively on acts or omissions occurring in Antarctica was upheld since the Federal Tort Claims Act's waiver of sovereign immunity did not apply to tort claims arising in Antarctica.

CaseName: Saudi Arabia, King Faisal Specialist Hospital And Royspec V. Scott Nelson Et Ux.
CaseSummary: Respondent was not entitled to damages he suffered from his imprisonment in petitioner country because the commercial activities of recruiting and hiring respondent to work for petitioner hospital were not the basis of respondent's tort action.

CaseName: Pioneer Investment Services Company V. Brunswick Associates Limited Partnership Et Al.
CaseSummary: An attorney's inadvertent failure to file a proof of claim within the deadline set by a bankruptcy court constituted excusable neglect within the meaning of a bankruptcy rule because the bankruptcy court's notification of the bar date was ambiguous.

CaseName: City Of Cincinnati V. Discovery Network, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A city's prohibition on the distribution of commercial handbills in newsracks on public property violated the First Amendment where a reasonable fit between the interests in safety and esthetics and the selective prohibition was not established.

CaseName: Fred H. Edenfield, Et Al. V. Scott Fane
CaseSummary: Judgment in favor of respondent affirmed because broad rules suppressing free expression, including legitimate commercial speech, infringe upon the free speech guarantees of the Constitution.

CaseName: Professional Real Estate Investors, Inc., Et Al. V. Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A copyright suit was not a sham for purposes of hotel owners' antitrust counterclaim. The copyright suit did not constitute a pursuit of claims so baseless that no reasonable litigant could realistically expect to secure favorable relief.

CaseName: William J. Mertens, Alex W. Bandrowski, James A. Clark, And Russell Franz V. Hewitt Associates
CaseSummary: The employees' suit against a nonfiduciary who knowingly participated in a breach of fiduciary duty imposed by ERISA was properly dismissed as the section authorizing suit to obtain "other appropriate equitable relief" did not include money damages.

CaseName: Musick, Peeler & Garrett, Et Al. V. Employers Insurance Of Wausau Et Al.
CaseSummary: An insurer was entitled to seek contribution from attorneys and accountants involved in misleading public offering in 10b-5 action because to allow right of contribution was consistent with Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

CaseName: Federal Communications Commission And United States V. Beach Communications, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A communications regulatory statute did not violate the equal protection guarantee of the Due Process Clause because the statutory classification neither proceeded along suspect lines nor infringed fundamental constitutional rights.

CaseName: Leonard Nobelman, Et Ux. V. American Savings Bank Et Al.
CaseSummary: Rejection of a confirmation of debtors' Chapter 13 plan that reduced an undersecured homestead mortgage to the fair market value of the property was proper because the bank's rights under the mortgage could not be modified.

CaseName: Lamb's Chapel And John Steigerwald V. Center Moriches Union Free School District Et Al.
CaseSummary: Summary judgment denying petitioners access to respondent's school property for public use was reversed because it was discrimination on the basis of viewpoint and nothing in the record supported the court's judgment.

CaseName: Jeffery Antoine V. Byers & Anderson, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Duties of court reporter were not functionally equivalent to those of judges, because they did not require the same kind of discretionary judgment, and court reporter was not, therefore, protected by judicial immunity.

CaseName: Donald Neal Rake, Et Al. V. William J. Wade, Trustee
CaseSummary: Although debtors' promissory notes did not allow interest on arrearages on their home mortgages, the Bankruptcy Code provided that an over-secured creditor was entitled to interest on the arrearages that debtors agreed to cure under their plans.

CaseName: Wisconsin V. Todd Mitchell
CaseSummary: Defendant's First Amendment freedom of speech and association rights were not violated by application of state penalty-enhancement provision in sentencing for racially-motivated aggravated assault; statute was not overbroad.

CaseName: Church Of The Lukumi Babalu Aye, Inc. And Ernesto Pichardo V. City Of Hialeah
CaseSummary: Ordinances passed by respondent city prohibiting animal sacrifice were found unconstitutional under the Free Exercise Clause because they were not neutral nor of general application and could not survive strict scrutiny.

CaseName: Concrete Pipe And Products Of California, Inc. V. Construction Laborers Pension Trust For Southern California
Larry Zobrest, Et Ux., Et Al. V. Catalina Foothills School District
CaseSummary: The Court held that the Establishment Clause did not prevent a school district from furnishing a deaf child with a sign language interpreter to facilitate his education at a sectarian school.

CaseName: Brooke Group Ltd. V. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation
CaseSummary: The Supreme Court held that petitioner had failed to prove that oligopolistic price coordination could cause primary-line competitive injury to the generic cigarette market; it did, however, refuse to create a per se rule of nonliability.

CaseName: United States And Federal Communications Commission V. Edge Broadcasting Company T/a Power 94
CaseSummary: A regulation banning advertisement of a lottery by a broadcaster licensed in a state that had banned gambling was constitutional where it was narrowly tailored to serve the governmental interest of respecting differing laws from neighboring states.

CaseName: Txo Production Corp. V. Alliance Resources Corp., Et Al.
CaseSummary: In respondents' slander of title suit involving an interest in oil and gas development rights, large punitive damage award against petitioner was affirmed, as award was not so grossly excessive as to violate petitioner's due process rights.

CaseName: Ferris J. Alexander, Sr. V. United States
CaseSummary: Forfeiture of a criminal's adult entertainment business as a penalty for violating the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act did not violate U.S. Const. amend. I as a prior restraint on the criminal's right to free speech.

CaseName: Hartford Fire Insurance Co., Et Al. V. California Et Al.
CaseSummary: A request by domestic and foreign insurers to dismiss a complaint for violations of antitrust laws was properly denied because the boycott exception of antitrust immunity under the McCarran-Ferguson Act was applicable.

CaseName: Teresa Harris V. Forklift Systems, Inc.
CaseSummary: Conduct barred by Title VII was not limited to conduct that would seriously affect a reasonable person's psychological well being. As long as the environment was reasonably perceived as hostile or abusive, was not required to be injurious to psyche.

CaseName: John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company V. Harris Trust And Savings Bank, As Trustee Of The Sperry Master Retirement Trust No. 2
CaseSummary: A guaranteed policy exclusion did not cover "free funds" administered by an insurer, because such funds were plan assets, and the insurer's actions in regard to their management were to be judged against ERISA's fiduciary standards.

CaseName: National Organization For Women, Inc., Etc., Et Al. V. Joseph Scheidler Et Al.
CaseSummary: A civil action under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act did not require proof that either the racketeering enterprise or the predicate acts alleged were motivated by an economic purpose.

CaseName: Department Of Revenue Of Oregon V. Acf Industries, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state may grant exemptions from a generally applicable ad valorem property tax without subjecting the taxation of railroad property to challenge under the Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976.

CaseName: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation V. John H. Meyer
CaseSummary: A former employee did not have a Bivens cause of action against the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, as it only applied to individuals not federal agencies.

CaseName: Luther R. Campbell Aka Luke Skyywalker, Et Al. V. Acuff-rose Music, Inc.
CaseSummary: In a copyright infringement action, a musical parody's commercial character was held to be only one element to be weighed in a fair use defense inquiry; such commercial character did not, in and of itself, prevent the parody from being a fair use.

CaseName: Oregon Waste Systems, Inc., Et Al. V. Department Of Environmental Quality Of The State Of Oregon Et Al.
CaseSummary: The United States Supreme Court invalidated out-of-state surcharges on solid waste disposal because State failed to demonstrate under Commerce Clause legitimate reason for imposing a surcharge on waste solely because it was generated in other states.

CaseName: J. E. B. V. Alabama Ex Rel. T. B.
CaseSummary: A State could not use its peremptory challenges in a paternity suit to exclude jurors solely on the basis of their gender because the exclusion was a violation the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

CaseName: Central Bank Of Denver, N. A. V. First Interstate Bank Of Denver, N. A. And Jack K. Naber
CaseSummary: Liability for aiding and abetting another's fraud was not imposed where an indenture trustee for bonds issued by a public housing authority was not a primary violator of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and had committed no deceptive acts.

CaseName: Mcdermott, Inc. V. Amclyde And River Don Castings Ltd.
CaseSummary: Respondents were entitled to have their damages allocation revised where the court found that a proportionate allocation among respondents was the correct approach.

CaseName: Boca Grande Club, Inc. V. Florida Power & Light Company, Inc.
City Of Chicago, Et Al. V. Environmental Defense Fund Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act did not exclude municipal waste combustion ash from the hazardous waste requirements of Subtitle C, such that the city's disposal of such ash at non-hazardous waste sites violated the Act.

CaseName: C & A Carbone, Inc., Et Al. V. Town Of Clarkstown, New York
CaseSummary: A local ordinance requiring all solid waste generated within a town to go to the town's recycling center actually impacted interstate commerce and violated the United States Constitution's Commerce Clause.

CaseName: Security Services, Inc. V. Kmart Corporation
CaseSummary: The court affirmed a judgment for respondent in petitioner debtor in possession's suit to collect undercharges pursuant to the filed rate doctrine since petitioner could not collect for undercharges based on filed, but void, rates.

CaseName: Bfp V. Resolution Trust Corporation, As Receiver Of Imperial Federal Savings Association, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A non-collusive and regularly conducted nonjudicial foreclosure sale could not be challenged as a fraudulent conveyance because the consideration received in such a sale established reasonably equivalent value as a matter of law.

CaseName: Associated Industries Of Missouri, Et Al. V. Janette M. Lohman, Director Of Revenue Of Missouri, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A statewide use tax was not a valid compensatory tax because local sales taxes did not precisely counterbalance the differential burdens placed by the tax on interstate and intrastate commerce as required by the Commerce Clause.

CaseName: Cynthia Waters, Et Al. V. Cheryl R. Churchill, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Employer and supervisor were not entitled to summary judgment in wrongful termination action. Employee produced enough evidence to create a material issue of disputed fact about employer's actual motivation for the employee's job termination.

CaseName: Pud No. 1 Of Jefferson County And City Of Tacoma V. Washington Department Of Ecology, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state could include minimum stream flow requirements in a certification for a hydroelectric project issued pursuant to the Clean Water Act insofar as necessary to enforce a designated use contained in a state water quality standard.

CaseName: Key Tronic Corporation V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: Polluter was not entitled to attorney's fees from other responsible party because CERCLA's contribution remedies did not expressly mention recovery of attorney's fees, yet some work done by attorneys was recoverable as a response cost.

CaseName: City Of Ladue, Et Al. V. Margaret P. Gilleo
CaseSummary: A city ordinance that prohibited homeowners from displaying signs was unconstitutional because it violated the First Amendment; there was no proof that adequate substitutes existed for the important medium of speech that the ordinance closed off.

CaseName: Albert Howlett V. Birkdale Shipping Co., S. A.
CaseSummary: Grant of summary judgment for shipowner was vacated because appellate court did not issue opinion and district court's opinion did not explore issues relevant to the shipowner's duty to warn a longshoreman of latent defects in a vessel.

CaseName: West Lynn Creamery, Inc., Et Al. V. Jonathan Healy, Commissioner Of Massachusetts Department Of Food And Agriculture
CaseSummary: Although tax imposed on all milk sold by dealers to state retailers was valid and a subsidy paid to state dairy farmers was also legitimate, use of tax collected from out-of-state dealers to subsidize in-state farmers violated the Commerce Clause.

CaseName: Mci Telecommunications Corporation V. American Telephone And Telegraph Company
CaseSummary: Ruling that the FCC's authorization of permissive detariffing violated the Communications Act was affirmed on review because the FCC exceeded the scope of its authority under the statute.

CaseName: Director, Office Of Workers' Compensation Programs, Department Of Labor V. Greenwich Collieries
CaseSummary: The Department of Labor's application of the "true doubt" rule, in adjudicating claims for black lung and workers' compensation benefits, improperly placed the burden of proof on the party opposing the benefit award.

CaseName: Barclays Bank Plc V. Franchise Tax Board Of California
CaseSummary: California Franchise Tax Board's imposition of corporate franchise tax on bank and company neither burdened foreign-based multinational entities nor was double international taxation contrary to Commerce and Due Process Clauses of U.S. Constitution.

CaseName: Honda Motor Co., Ltd., Et Al. V. Karl L. Oberg
CaseSummary: Oregon's denial of judicial review of the size of punitive damage awards violated the Due Process Clause because Oregon removed the safeguard without providing any substitute procedure.

CaseName: Consolidated Rail Corporation V. James E. Gottshall
CaseSummary: Witness's action for negligent infliction of emotional distress against railroad was remanded under the common-law zone-of-danger test, which was consistent with the remedial goals and focus on physical perils under Federal Employers' Liability Act.

CaseName: Turner Broadcasting System, Inc., Et Al. V. Federal Communications Commission Et Al.
CaseSummary: Although must-carry provision of Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act was content-neutral and thus not subject to heightened scrutiny, law was invalid without proof of economic need for restrictions on constitutional rights.

CaseName: Board Of Education Of Kiryas Joel Village School District V. Louis Grumet Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state statute departed from a course of neutrality toward religion by delegating the state's discretionary authority over public schools to a group defined by its character as a religious community.

CaseName: Judy Madsen, Et Al. V. Women's Health Center, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: The court upheld the noise restrictions and the buffer zone around the clinic entrances and driveway as they burdened no more speech than necessary to eliminate the unlawful conduct targeted by the state court's injunction.

CaseName: Albert Hess And Charles F. Walsh V. Port Authority Trans-hudson Corporation
CaseSummary: Requiring a bi-state railway to answer in a federal court to a complaint filed by the injured railroad workers who asserted a federal statutory right to recover damages, did not touch the concerns that underpinned the Eleventh Amendment.

CaseName: United States V. X-citement Video, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Protection of Children Against Sexual Exploitation Act of 1977, banning the interstate transportation of child pornography, was constitutional because it required knowledge that at least one of the video performers was a minor.

CaseName: Charles J. Reich V. Marcus E. Collins, Revenue Commissioner Of Georgia, Et Al.
CaseSummary: State's denial of a refund of taxes, which were paid by a federal retiree on his retirement benefits under a tax scheme that had been declared unconstitutional, violated the Due Process Clause because no means of redress was provided by tax statute.

CaseName: Asgrow Seed Company V. Denny Winterboer And Becky Winterboer, Dba Deebees
CaseSummary: The Plant Variety Protection Act of 1970 permitted respondent farmer to only resell his seeds that he bought from petitioner seed company that were capable of being replanted on his own farm.

CaseName: Christine Mckennon V. Nashville Banner Publishing Company
Michael A. Lebron V. National Railroad Passenger Corporation
CaseSummary: Respondent corporation was a government actor for First Amendment purposes where it was created by special law for the furtherance of government objectives and the government retained authority to appoint its directors.

CaseName: Milwaukee Brewery Workers' Pension Plan V. Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company And Stroh Brewery Company
CaseSummary: The interest that accrued on a withdrawal charge liability that withdrawing employers from a multiemployer plan amortized did not accrue until the first day of the year following withdrawal from the plan.

CaseName: United States, Et Al. V. National Treasury Employees Union Et Al.
CaseSummary: Honoraria ban that prohibited federal employees from accepting compensation for making speeches or writing articles even when the speech had no connection with the employee's official duties violated the First Amendment.

CaseName: Arthur L. Gustafson, Et Al. V. Alloyd Company, Incorporated, Fka Alloyd Holdings, Incorporated, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Purchaser of stock through a private sale could not rescind purchase under Securities Act of 1933 (Act) based on inaccurate financial recitations in purchase agreement because the word prospectus, as used in Act, referred only to public offerings.

CaseName: Antonio Mastrobuono And Diana G. Mastrobuono V. Shearson Lehman Hutton, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Agreement selecting a state for choice of law meant that only that state's substantive law applied to the parties' disagreement, but arbitration rules permitted the arbitration panel to award punitive damages, despite state's law to the contrary.

CaseName: Curtiss-wright Corporation V. Frank C. Schoonejongen, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Company's amendment procedure stating that it reserved the right at any time to amend the plan properly satisfied ERISA requirements, but determination of whether amendment procedure was complied with was needed.

CaseName: Qualitex Company V. Jacobson Products Company, Inc.
CaseSummary: Petitioner was entitled to register a color as a trademark to the extent it met the ordinary requirements to register a trademark as long as its use as a mark would not permit petitioner to interfere with legitimate competition.

CaseName: Oklahoma Tax Commission V. Jefferson Lines, Inc.
CaseSummary: Oklahoma's sales tax on the full price of a ticket for bus travel from Oklahoma to another state was consistent with the Commerce Clause and "the negative Commerce Clause."

CaseName: Donna E. Shalala, Secretary Of Health And Human Services V. Margaret Whitecotton Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where claimant's injuries first manifested before vaccination, claimant failed to make out a prima facie case for compensation under the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act of 1986.

CaseName: George W. Heintz, Et Al. V. Darlene Jenkins
CaseSummary: A debtor had a claim against lawyers under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act because the term "debt collector" applied to a lawyer who regularly, though litigation, tried to collect consumer debts.

CaseName: Joseph Mcintyre, Executor Of Estate Of Margaret Mcintyre, Deceased V. Ohio Elections Commission
CaseSummary: Statute prohibiting distribution of anonymous campaign literature was invalid as it abridged freedom of speech. The statute was not narrowly tailored to serve an overriding state interest.

CaseName: Robert E. Rubin, Secretary Of The Treasury V. Coors Brewing Company
CaseSummary: The Federal Alcohol Administration Act invalidly infringed on a brewer's freedom of speech because the act was more extensive than necessary to serve the government's interest in preventing competition on the basis of alcohol strength.

CaseName: First Options Of Chicago, Inc. V. Manuel Kaplan, Et Ux. And Mk Investments, Inc.
CaseSummary: Stock trader and wife never agreed to arbitrate arbitrability of dispute with clearinghouse. Court of appeals correctly held arbitrability issue was subject to review de novo for questions of law and clearly erroneous review for questions of fact.

CaseName: City Of Milwaukee V. Cement Division, National Gypsum Company, Et Al.
CaseSummary: City was liable for prejudgment interest after it was found one-third negligent for damage caused to company's vessel because the existence of mutual fault did not justify the denial of prejudgment interest in an admiralty collision case.

CaseName: Metropolitan Stevedore Company V. John Rambo Et Al.
CaseSummary: For purposes of modifying a disability award under the Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act, a change of conditions could include a change in a claimant's earning capacity, even when there was no change in his physical condition.

CaseName: Chandris, Inc., Et Al. V. Antonios Latsis
CaseSummary: On writ of certiorari, order vacating a judgment in favor of a ship owner was affirmed because the Jones Act remedy could be available to maritime workers who spent a portion of their time working on shore but spent the rest of their time at sea.

CaseName: Vimar Seguros Y Reaseguros, S. A. V. M/v Sky Reefer, Her Engines, Etc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: The increased cost of litigating in a distant forum did not lessen liability as that terms was used in the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act. Thus an arbitration clause in a bill of lading was enforceable.

CaseName: John J. Hurley And South Boston Allied War Veterans Council V. Irish-american Gay, Lesbian And Bisexual Group Of Boston, Etc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Petitioners' First Amendment rights to free speech were violated by the application of a state statute to force petitioners to include groups in their parade who espoused beliefs with which petitioners did not agree.

CaseName: Bruce Babbitt, Secretary Of The Interior, Et Al. V. Sweet Home Chapter Of Communities For A Great Oregon Et Al.
CaseSummary: Endangered Species Act regulation defining harm to include habitat modification and degradation was reasonable because ordinary understanding of harm encompassed habitat modification that resulted in actual injury or death to endangered species.

CaseName: Capitol Square Review And Advisory Board, Et Al. V. Vincent J. Pinette, Donnie A. Carr And Knights Of The Ku Klux Klan
CaseSummary: Respondents entitled to display cross on government property, as Establishment Clause not violated where religious speech was purely private, occurred in a public forum, was publicly announced and open to all on equal terms.

CaseName: Ronald W. Rosenberger, Et Al. V. Rector And Visitors Of The University Of Virginia Et Al.
CaseSummary: By excluding a student publication from participating in a student activities fund solely on the basis of the publication's religious viewpoint, a state university engaged in content discrimination and violated the First Amendment.

CaseName: Citizens Bank Of Maryland V. David Strumpf
CaseSummary: Creditor bank's administrative hold on bankruptcy debtor's checking account did not violate the automatic stay imposed by the Bankruptcy Code because bank did not purport to permanently reduce debtor's account balance by amount of the defaulted loan.

CaseName: William Field And Norinne Field V. Philip W. Mans
CaseSummary: Discharge of an individual's debt in bankruptcy was improper, because bankruptcy court erroneously required creditors to show "reasonable reliance" upon debtor's false representations to avoid discharge. Correct standard was justifiable reliance.

CaseName: Yamaha Motor Corporation, U. S. A., Et Al. V. Lucien B. Calhoun, Et Al., Individually And As Administrators Of The Estate Of Calhoun, Deceased
CaseSummary: Where state wrongful death remedies were available in a case where the decedent was not a seaman or a longshore worker and died in a collision on navigable waters, such remedies were not displaced by a federal maritime wrongful death cause of action.

CaseName: Marjorie Zicherman, Etc., Et Al. V. Korean Air Lines Co., Ltd.
CaseSummary: Warsaw Convention permitted compensation only for legally cognizable harm, but left specification of what harm was cognizable to domestic law; where an airplane crash occurred on high seas, Death on the High Seas Act supplied substantive law.

CaseName: Lotus Development Corporation V. Borland International, Inc.
Bank One Chicago, N. A. V. Midwest Bank & Trust Company
CaseSummary: Federal courts had subject matter jurisdiction, pursuant to the Expedited Funds Availability Act, over suits brought by one bank against another bank, as well as suits initiated by bank customers against banks.

CaseName: Fulton Corporation V. Janice H. Faulkner, Secretary Of Revenue Of North Carolina
CaseSummary: An intangibles tax scheme based on taxable percentage deduction that was facially discriminatory against out-of-state corporations could not be sustained as compensatory levy without proof of in-state activity.

CaseName: D. Grant Peacock V. Jack L. Thomas
CaseSummary: Exercise of ancillary jurisdiction has never been authorized in a subsequent lawsuit to impose an obligation to pay an existing federal judgment on a person not already liable for that judgment.

CaseName: Norfolk & Western Railway Co. V. Hiles
CaseSummary: Misaligned drawbar did not constitute a violation of the Safety Appliance Act, and thus employee hurting himself attempting to correct that misalignment could not bring a Safety Appliance Act lawsuit.

CaseName: Hercules Incorporated, Et Al. V. United States
CaseSummary: Government contracts did not contain warranties or indemnification provisions for costs in defending and settling third-party tort claims resulting from chemical manufacture and use, and no recovery could therefore be had against the government.

CaseName: Varity Corporation V. Charles Howe Et Al.
CaseSummary: Under specific factual circumstances, employer acted in its capacity as an ERISA fiduciary when it significantly and deliberately misled the plan's beneficiaries, thereby violating its fiduciary obligations imposed by ERISA.

CaseName: 44 Liquormart, Inc. And Peoples Super Liquor Stores, Inc. V. Rhode Island And Rhode Island Liquor Stores Association
CaseSummary: Statutes which prohibited alcohol pricing advertisements were struck down as unconstitutional under the First Amendment where Court held they did not directly advance government's interest in reducing alcohol consumption.

CaseName: Bmw Of North America, Inc. V. Ira Gore, Jr.
CaseSummary: An award of punitive damages that was 500 times larger than compensatory damages that were awarded was found to be excessive in a suit involving a car distributor's failure to disclose to a car owner the pre-delivery repairs made to a new vehicle.

CaseName: Roy Romer, Governor Of Colorado, Et Al. V. Richard G. Evans Et Al.
CaseSummary: State constitutional amendment that drew classification based on sexual orientation not to further a proper legislative end but to make gays unequal to everyone else was unconstitutional; the amendment withdrew only from gays legal protection.

CaseName: Exxon Company, U. S. A., Et Al. V. Sofec, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Petitioner could not recover in admiralty for the loss of its ship and cargo where petitioner was the superseding and sole proximate cause of its own injury.

CaseName: Lockheed Corporation, Et Al. V. Paul L. Spink
CaseSummary: Employer's amendment of benefits plan to condition payment of early retirement benefits on waiver of employment-related claims did not violate ERISA where employer was not acting as fiduciary and payment of benefits was not prohibited transaction.

CaseName: James Griffin Lane V. Federico F. Pena, Secretary Of Transportation, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Compensatory damages were properly denied to student separated from a military academy for the disqualifying condition of diabetes because the Rehabilitation Act lacked a clear expression waiving sovereign immunity against awards of monetary damages.

CaseName: Antony Brown, Et Al. V. Pro Football, Inc., Dba Washington Redskins, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Federal labor law waived antitrust liability for restraints on competition imposed through the collective bargaining process, so long as such restraints operated in a labor market characterized by collective bargaining.

CaseName: United States V. Virginia Et Al.
CaseSummary: A party seeking to uphold government action based on sex must show classification serves important governmental objectives and that discriminatory means employed are substantially related to achievement of those objectives.

CaseName: Colorado Republican Federal Campaign Committee And Douglas Jones, Treasurer V. Federal Election Commission
CaseSummary: The Court vacated a judgment that expenditures made by a political party prior to nominating a candidate were covered by limitations imposed by the Federal Election Campaign Act because the First Amendment prohibited application of the limitations.

CaseName: Bd. Of County Comm'rs V. Umbehr
CaseSummary: The First Amendment protected an independent contractor, like a public employee, from the termination of his at-will governmental contract by a county board of commissioners in retaliation for the contractor's public criticism of the board.

CaseName: O'hare Truck Service, Incorporated, Et Al. V. City Of Northlake Et Al.
CaseSummary: Free speech provisions of the First Amendment protected political statements made by petitioner, a governmental independent contractor.

CaseName: Denver Area Educational Telecommunications Consortium, Inc., Et Al. V. Federal Communications Commission Et Al.
CaseSummary: Supreme Court held two of three statutory provisions regarding broadcast of patently offensive programs challenged by petitioners violated U.S. Const. amend. I because they were not narrowly tailored to protect children.

CaseName: United States V. Winstar Corporation, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where petitioner federal government specifically contracted to accept liability incurred in the event of subsequent legislative enactments, they were obligated to compensate respondent savings and loans for damages resulting from such enactments.

CaseName: John W. Atherton, Jr. V. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, As Receiver For City Savings, F. S. B.
CaseSummary: A judgment reversing the dismissal of claims against bank officers, except gross negligence claims, was vacated and the case remanded where state law set the standard of care to measure conduct and federal statute set gross negligence.

CaseName: Ingalls Shipbuilding, Inc., Et Al. V. Director, Office Of Workers' Compensation Programs, Department Of Labor, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A widow who entered into unapproved pre-death settlements did not forfeit her eligibility for death benefits because she was not eligible to receive those benefits before her spouse died under the Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act.

CaseName: General Motors Corporation V. Roger W. Tracy, Tax Commissioner Of Ohio
CaseSummary: State regulatory scheme allowing different tax rates for domestic regulated natural gas companies than for other entities was permissible because the enterprises were not similarly situated for purposes of the Commerce Clause.

CaseName: Paul Schenck And Dwight Saunders V. Pro-choice Network Of Western New York Et Al.
CaseSummary: An injunction that prohibited protest demonstrations within fixed zones around abortion clinics was constitutionally permissible, but the creation of floating buffer zones around people seeking access to the clinics improperly burdened free speech.

CaseName: Regents Of The University Of California, Et Al. V. John Doe Etc.
CaseSummary: In a breach of contract action, Eleventh Amendment immunity protected the State-wide university system from the risk of adverse judgments even though the university system was indemnified by the Federal Government.

CaseName: William C. Dunn And Delta Consultants, Inc. V. Commodity Futures Trading Commission Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission was not authorized to regulate "off-exchange" trading in options to buy or sell foreign currency except as to transactions conducted on a board of trade.

CaseName: Warner-jenkinson Company, Inc., Et Al. V. Hilton Davis Chemical Co.
CaseSummary: The Court reversed and remanded the lower court's decision for further proceedings, as the court below, in deciding that petitioner infringed upon respondent's patent, failed to consider all of the requirements under the doctrine of equivalents.

CaseName: Turner Broadcasting System, Inc., Et Al. V. Federal Communications Commission Et Al.
CaseSummary: Summary judgment entered against appellants was affirmed because the must-carry provisions of the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act were content-neutral restrictions on speech that passed U.S. Const. amend. I scrutiny.

CaseName: Inter-modal Rail Employees Association, Et Al. V. Atchison, Topeka And Santa Fe Railway Company, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Appellate court erred in holding that the ERISA section, which barred employers from discharging employees so as to interfere with their attainment of rights to which they would have become entitled under ERISA plans, applied only to vested rights.

CaseName: Harbor Tug And Barge Company V. John Papai Et Ux.
CaseSummary: The essential requirements for seaman status are that an employee's duties contributed to the function of the vessel and the seaman had a substantial connection to a vessel in navigation in terms of duration and nature.

CaseName: Camps Newfound/owatonna, Inc. V. Town Of Harrison, Maine, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A real estate tax on a non-profit camp that served primarily out of state students violated the Commerce Clause because non-profit camps that served primarily in state students were exempt from paying the tax.

CaseName: William Jefferson Clinton V. Paula Corbin Jones
CaseSummary: The doctrine of separation of powers does not require federal courts to stay all private actions against the President of the U.S. until he leaves office.

CaseName: Saratoga Fishing Company V. J. M. Martinac & Company And Marco Seattle Inc.
CaseSummary: Extra fishing equipment and spare parts, added to a ship by a user after an initial sale, were not part of the original ship with a defective hydraulic system that itself caused the harm and thus, were compensable "other property" losses.

CaseName: Hughes Aircraft Company V. United States, Ex Rel. William J. Schumer
CaseSummary: The amended False Claims Act was not applied retroactively to revive an otherwise barred claim when there was no clear congressional intent that the amendment be applied retroactively and when it eliminated a defense that affected substantive rights.

CaseName: Associates Commercial Corporation V. Elray Rash Et Ux.
CaseSummary: Where debtors invoked cram down power to retain secured property for business use, property's present value was determined by its replacement value; debtors' actual use of property and value from creditor's perspective were material.

CaseName: Metropolitan Stevedore Company V. John Rambo Et Al.
CaseSummary: The trial court improperly ended the compensation of an injured employee able to earn as much after the injury as he was prior to the injury, and was required to make findings of fact as to whether further nominal compensation was to be awarded.

CaseName: Rachel Agostini, Et Al. V. Betty-louise Felton Et Al.
CaseSummary: A federally funded program providing instruction to children on a neutral basis was valid under the Establishment Clause when such instruction was given on the premises of sectarian schools by government employees.

CaseName: Metro-north Commuter Railroad Company V. Michael Buckley
CaseSummary: Exposure to asbestos by an employee was insufficient "physical impact" to substantiate a claim for damages for emotional distress because the employee had not exhibited any symptoms of any disease from the exposure.

CaseName: Dan Glickman, Secretary Of Agriculture V. Wileman Brothers & Elliott, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: First Amendment rights of fruit growers, handlers, and processors were not violated by government mandated contributions to pay for generic fruit advertising where market participants and legislature deemed such collective programs to be beneficial.

CaseName: City Of Boerne V. P. F. Flores, Archbishop Of San Antonio, And United States
CaseSummary: The Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 was not constitutional because it afforded Congress the opportunity to exceed the scope of its enforcement powers under the constitution.

CaseName: United States V. James Herman O'hagan
CaseSummary: A Securities Exchange Commission Rule was the proper exercise of the Commission's prophylactic powers under the Securities Exchange Act regarding prevention of the misappropriation charged against respondent.

CaseName: Janet Reno, Attorney General Of The United States, Et Al. V. American Civil Liberties Union Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Communications Decency Act of 1996 was held violative of the First Amendment due to its being overbroad; the statute criminalized constitutionally-protected indecent speech as well as unprotected obscene speech.

CaseName: State Oil Company V. Barkat U. Khan And Khan & Associates, Inc.
CaseSummary: Order reversing summary judgment for oil company in antitrust suit was vacated and case remanded where vertical maximum price fixing was not per se Sherman Act violation and such price fixing arrangements were to be evaluated under rule of reason.

CaseName: Bay Area Laundry And Dry Cleaning Pension Trust Fund V. Ferbar Corporation Of California, Inc., And Stephen Barnes
CaseSummary: Statute of limitation on withdrawal payments, owed under the Multiemployer Pension Plan Amendments Act of 1980, began to run when each payment was due and owing, not on date employer first withdrew from participation in pension plan.

CaseName: Fidelity Financial Services, Inc. V. Richard V. Fink, Trustee
CaseSummary: A creditor's lien was a voidable preference under the Bankruptcy Code because the creditor was entitled to invoke the enabling loan exception only by acting to perfect a security interest within 20-days of possession.

CaseName: Christopher H. Lunding, Et Ux. V. New York Tax Appeals Tribunal Et Al.
CaseSummary: A New York statute that effectively denied only nonresident taxpayers an income tax deduction for alimony paid was deemed inconsistent with the Privileges and Immunities Clause, absent justification for discriminatory treatment of nonresidents.

CaseName: National Credit Union Administration V. First National Bank & Trust Co. Et Al.
CaseSummary: Banks and a banking association had standing to challenge National Credit Union Association's construction of the Federal Credit Union Act; and construing the Act to admit unrelated employer groups to credit union membership was erroneous.

CaseName: Daniel Bogan And Marilyn Roderick V. Janet Scott-harris
CaseSummary: City council vice-president had absolute legislative immunity from federal civil rights action that involved her voting for a proposed ordinance. The mayor had absolute legislative immunity for proposing the ordinance and signing it into law.

CaseName: Margaret Kawaauhau, Et Vir V. Paul W. Geiger
CaseSummary: Where judgment creditors challenged the discharge in bankruptcy of a malpractice judgment debt owed by a physician, debt was properly discharged because only debts resulting from an actual intent to cause injury were not dischargeable in bankruptcy.

CaseName: Joseph Oncale V. Sundowner Offshore Services, Incorporated, Et Al.
CaseSummary: An order denying an employee relief against his employer under Title VII was overturned because sex discrimination consisting of same-sex sexual harassment in the context of a "hostile environment" claim was actionable under Title VII.

CaseName: Quality King Distributors, Inc. V. L'anza Research International, Inc.
CaseSummary: Copyright Act did not prohibit petitioner's unauthorized importation and resale of copyrighted labels from respondent's foreign distributor, as distribution right did not encompass reselling by lawful owners, under first sale doctrine.

CaseName: Edward S. Cohen V. Hilda De La Cruz Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where a debtor challenged the nondischargeability in bankruptcy of a debt owed to certain tenants, the United States Supreme Court affirmed the refusal to discharge the debt to the tenants because liability arose from fraudulently obtained payments.

CaseName: C. Elvin Feltner, Jr. V. Columbia Pictures Television, Inc.
CaseSummary: Petitioner, who was found liable for infringing respondent's copyrights, was entitled under the Seventh Amendment to a jury trial on the issue of the amount of statutory damages sought by respondent.

CaseName: David R. Beach, Et Ux. V. Ocwen Federal Bank
CaseSummary: Borrowers were not entitled to assert and revive statutory right of rescission provided by the Truth in Lending Act as an affirmative defense to lender's foreclosure suit because the mortgage transaction had been consummated over three years earlier.

CaseName: Arkansas Educational Television Commission V. Ralph P. Forbes
CaseSummary: Political candidate's objective lack of support, not his political platform, was a permissible basis on which to exclude him from a nonpublic forum debate.

CaseName: County Of Sacramento, Et Al. V. Teri Lewis And Thomas Lewis, Personal Representatives Of The Estate Of Philip Lewis, Deceased
CaseSummary: Petitioner police officer was not liable to respondent passenger because petitioner's involvement in a chase with no intent to harm respondent physically or to worsen his legal plight did not give rise to liability for a due process right to life.

CaseName: United States V. Bestfoods, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Reversal of ruling that succeeding parent corporations of chemical plant were liable to pay for the clean up of a hazardous waste site per CERCLA, had to be remanded and the participation-and-control test was inapplicable.

CaseName: Bonnie L. Geissal, Beneficiary And Representative Of The Estate Of James W. Geissal, Deceased V. Moore Medical Corporation Et Al.
CaseSummary: An employer was unable to terminate health plan continuation coverage for a qualified beneficiary who was also covered under his wife's group health plan because the secondary plan was in effect prior to the date of the employee's COBRA election.

CaseName: Philomena Dooley, Personal Representative Of The Estate Of Cecelio Chuapoco, Et Al. V. Korean Air Lines Co., Ltd.
CaseSummary: The vacating of a punitive damages award to representatives of decedents who were passengers on a commercial plane that was shot down over the sea was proper because Death on the High Seas Act limited the available recovery to pecuniary losses.

CaseName: Alida Star Gebser And Alida Jean Mccullough V. Lago Vista Independent School District
CaseSummary: A student was not allowed to recover from a school district for sexual harassment by one of the district's teachers because an official of the school district did not have actual notice of and was not deliberately indifferent to the misconduct.

CaseName: National Endowment For The Arts, Et Al. V. Karen Finley, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The requirement of "decency and respect" as criteria for federal grant consideration in a subjective selection process by National Foundation for the Arts was neither constitutionally vague nor facially invalid.

CaseName: Burlington Industries, Inc. V. Kimberly B. Ellerth
CaseSummary: Petitioner employer was subject to vicarious liability to respondent employee for an actionable hostile work environment created by a supervisor with immediate authority over respondent when no tangible employment action was taken.

CaseName: Beth Ann Faragher V. City Of Boca Raton
CaseSummary: An employer could be held vicariously liable under Title VII for a hostile work environment caused by a supervisor, but subject to an affirmative defense looking to the reasonableness of the employer's conduct as well as that of the victim.

CaseName: Wayne K. Pfaff V. Wells Electronics, Inc.
CaseSummary: The on-sale bar to patentability applied to petitioner's invention, since more than one year before the patent application the invention had been commercially marketed and was ready for patenting, as evidenced by detailed drawings of the device.

CaseName: Nynex Corporation, Et Al. V. Discon, Incorporated
CaseSummary: The court of appeals erred in applying the per se group boycott rule to an antitrust case where a single buyer favored one seller over another, albeit for an improper reason.

CaseName: El Al Israel Airlines, Ltd. V. Tsui Yuan Tseng
CaseSummary: Where a passenger was barred from pursuing a tort action against an airline on the basis that her suit was precluded by the Warsaw Convention, she could not pursue an action in state court because the Warsaw Convention provided the exclusive remedy.

CaseName: Victoria Buckley, Secretary Of State Of Colorado V. American Constitutional Law Foundation, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Regulations on political speech, specifically on the ballot election process, were struck down by the court where they were overly restrictive and did not serve the state's valid interest in protecting the integrity of the political process.

CaseName: Jane M. Roberts, Guardian For Wanda Y. Johnson V. Galen Of Virginia, Inc., Formerly Dba Humana Hospital University Of Louisville, Dba University Of Louisville Hospital
CaseSummary: Showing of improper motive was not required in order for patient to recover upon a claim under the Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act that hospital failed to stabilize her condition before moving her to a permanent care facility.

CaseName: Department Of The Army V. Blue Fox, Inc.
CaseSummary: A subcontractor was not able to proceed on its equitable lien against a military department because the department was protected by immunity and waiver did not apply under the Administrative Procedure Act.

CaseName: At&t Corporation, Et Al. V. Iowa Utilities Board Et Al.
CaseSummary: Government agency's local competition rules imposed upon local exchange carriers were not beyond its jurisdiction where it had the authority to carry out provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.

CaseName: Hughes Aircraft Company, Et Al. V. Stanley I. Jacobson Et Al.
CaseSummary: In class action brought by retired beneficiaries of benefit plan, claiming violations of ERISA by their former employer, the Court held that beneficiaries failed to show that employer labored under fiduciary duties or engaged in a sham transaction.

CaseName: National Collegiate Athletic Association V. R. M. Smith
CaseSummary: Receipt of dues from federally funded member institutions by NCAA demonstrated that it only indirectly benefitted from such assistance, which was insufficient to afford coverage to plaintiff under Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972.

CaseName: South Central Bell Telephone Company, Et Al. V. Alabama Et Al.
CaseSummary: Respondent state's franchise tax violated the Commerce Clause because domestic corporations could reduce their tax liability by simply reducing the par value of their stock while petitioner taxpayers, foreign corporations, were denied that ability.

CaseName: David Conn And Carol Najera V. Paul L. Gabbert
CaseSummary: An attorney, who was searched at the same time his client testified before a grand jury, was not entitled to bring a § 1983 action against the prosecutor because the prosecutor directing the search did not violate the attorney's right to practice.

CaseName: Unum Life Insurance Company Of America V. John E. Ward
CaseSummary: Reversal of grant of summary judgment for petitioner was affirmed since state's notice-prejudice rule was a law which regulated insurance and was not preempted by ERISA, but agency law did relate to employee benefit plans and was preempted.

CaseName: United States V. Sun-diamond Growers Of California
CaseSummary: Conviction under the federal illegal gratuity statute was properly overturned, where government failed to link the fact that a thing of value was given to a public official to a specific official act, for or because of which the gift was given.

CaseName: Bank Of America National Trust And Savings Association V. 203 North Lasalle Street Partnership
CaseSummary: Respondent debtor's prebankruptcy equity holders were unable to contribute new capital and receive ownership interests in the reorganized entity when that opportunity was given exclusively to the old equity holders under a reorganization plan.

CaseName: Aurelia Davis, As Next Friend Of Lashonda D. V. Monroe County Board Of Education Et Al.
CaseSummary: A school district, a Title IX funding recipient, could be liable for deliberate indifference to known acts of peer sexual harassment that were so severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive that victim's access to educational benefit was barred.

CaseName: California Dental Association V. Federal Trade Commission
CaseSummary: Respondent agency had jurisdiction under the FTC Act over petitioner association because it provided substantial benefit to its members, but because disputed anticompetitive efforts were not obvious, more than a rule-of-reason analysis was required.

CaseName: Amoco Production Company, On Behalf Of Itself And The Class It Represents V. Southern Ute Indian Tribe Et Al.
CaseSummary: Congress' interpretation of coal almost a century ago was a solid rock substance and did not encompass coalbed methane gas; thus, the gas was not reserved to the United States under a land patent.

CaseName: Greater New Orleans Broadcasting Association, Inc., Etc., Et Al. V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: Restrictions on advertisements of private casino gambling that were broadcast by radio or television stations located in Louisiana where such gambling was legal violated the First Amendment.

CaseName: Los Angeles Police Department V. United Reporting Publishing Corporation
CaseSummary: Statute regulating access to arrestees' addresses held by police was not facially invalid. State could decide not to give out arrestee information at all without violating the First Amendment.

CaseName: Jeremiah W. (Jay) Nixon, Attorney General Of Missouri, Et Al. V. Shrink Missouri Government Pac Et Al.
CaseSummary: A Missouri law that limited contributions to state political candidates did not violate the First Amendment because the prevention of corruption and the appearance of corruption was a legitimate government purpose.

CaseName: Chad Weisgram, Et Al. V. Marley Company, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The authority of courts of appeals to direct the entry of judgment as a matter of law extended to cases in which, on excision of testimony erroneously admitted, there remained insufficient evidence to support the jury's verdict.

CaseName: Hunt-wesson, Inc. V. Franchise Tax Board Of California
CaseSummary: Offset provision of state tax law that measured allowable interest expense deduction based on interest and dividends of nonunitary income was impermissible taxation of petitioner's income, outside the state's jurisdictional reach.

CaseName: Food And Drug Administration, Et Al. V. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Based on the overall regulatory scheme of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and subsequent tobacco litigation, it was clear that Congress precluded the Food and Drug Administration from regulating tobacco products.

CaseName: Wal-mart Stores, Inc. V. Samara Brothers, Inc.
CaseSummary: In a clothing designer's action against a retailer for infringement of unregistered trade dress under the Lanham Act, the designer's product's design was distinctive, and therefore protectible, only upon a showing of secondary meaning.

CaseName: Board Of Regents Of The University Of Wisconsin System V. Scott Harold Southworth, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The First Amendment permitted a public university to charge its students a mandatory activity fee used to fund a program to facilitate extracurricular student speech where the program was viewpoint neutral in the allocation of funding support.

CaseName: City Of Erie, Et Al. V. Pap's A. M., Tdba 'Kandyland'
CaseSummary: Ordinance banning public nudity was content-neutral as City's interest in preventing harmful secondary effects of totally nude dancing was not related to suppression of exotic message conveyed; ordinance was constitutional.

CaseName: Public Lands Council, Et Al. V. Bruce Babbitt, Secretary Of The Interior, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Changes in regulations governing grazing preferences, permit issuance, and ownership of range improvements held not to have exceeded the statutory authority of the Secretary of the Interior pursuant to the Taylor Grazing Act.

CaseName: United States, Et Al. V. Playboy Entertainment Group, Inc.
CaseSummary: Requiring cable television operators to fully scramble or limit time when sexually-oriented programming was transmitted violated First Amendment because government failed to show that it was least restrictive means.

CaseName: Hartford Underwriters Insurance Company V. Union Planters Bank, N. A.
CaseSummary: Creditor's claim was properly denied, since it was an administrative claimant of a bankruptcy estate, and could not seek payment of its claim from property encumbered by a secured creditor's lien.

CaseName: Thomas E. Raleigh, Chapter 7 Trustee For The Estate Of William J. Stoecker, V. Illinois Department Of Revenue
CaseSummary: Where a state's tax laws put the burden of proof on the taxpayer once a notice of penalty liability was issued and the Bankruptcy Code made no provision for altering it, the burden of proof on a tax claim in bankruptcy remained on the taxpayer.

CaseName: Lori Pegram, Et Al. V. Cynthia Herdrich
CaseSummary: Mixed eligibility decision to delay medical treatment by sending patient to HMO owned facility, with adverse consequences, made by health maintenance organization through its physician was not fiduciary decision under ERISA.

CaseName: Harris Trust And Savings Bank, Etc., Et Al. V. Salomon Smith Barney Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A private cause of action by a trustee and administrator against a nonfiduciary who participated in a prohibited transaction was allowed under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act.

CaseName: Santa Fe Independent School District V. Jane Doe, Individually And As Next Friend For Her Minor Children, Jane And John Doe, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A school district's policy permitting student-led, student-initiated prayer prior to school football games violated the Establishment Clause of the U.S. Constitution.

CaseName: Mobil Oil Exploration And Producing Southeast, Inc. V. United States
CaseSummary: Where a new statute prevented the United States from keeping a contractual promise, it repudiated the lease contracts and petitioners were entitled to restitution whether or not the contracts would have ultimately produced a financial gain.

CaseName: Boy Scouts Of America And Monmouth Council, Et Al. V. James Dale
CaseSummary: Application of state public accommodations law intruded on organizations' right to freedom of association. Group's official position against homosexuality supported its expulsion of plaintiff as a valid exercise of the right.

CaseName: Leila Jeanne Hill, Audrey Himmelmann, And Everitt W. Simpson, Jr. V. Colorado, Et Al.
CaseSummary: State statute providing an eight foot bubble zone around people entering a health care facility was upheld as a valid restriction on speech, serving significant and legitimate governmental interests.

CaseName: Guy Mitchell, Et Al. V. Mary L. Helms, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Law that provided aid to public and private schools did not unconstitutionally advance religion because it neither resulted in religious indoctrination by government nor defined recipients by religious reference.

CaseName: Don Stenberg, Attorney General Of Nebraska, Et Al. V. Leroy Carhart
CaseSummary: State statute criminalizing "partial birth abortions" was unconstitutional because it lacked exception for preservation of mother's health and burdened choice of more common abortion procedure, unduly burdening right to abortion itself.

CaseName: Solid Waste Agency Of Northern Cook County V. United States Army Corps Of Engineers, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Even though proposed waste disposal site was migratory bird habitat, federal agency jurisdiction did not extend to nonnavigable, isolated, intrastate gravel pit where clean water statute limited jurisdiction to navigable waters.

CaseName: Director Of Revenue Of Missouri V. Cobank Acb, As Successor To The National Bank Of Cooperatives
CaseSummary: Banks for cooperatives were subject to state taxation; deletion of superfluous language in Farm Credit Act (FCA) was not repeal of previous express approval of state taxation, and structure of FCA negatively implied that there was no immunity.

CaseName: Central Green Co. V. United States
CaseSummary: Federal government's immunity from liability for flood damage required determination of whether actual flows through government's canal constituted flood waters, regardless of canal's flood control purposes.

CaseName: James F. Lewis V. Lewis & Clark Marine, Inc., Etc.
CaseSummary: Dissolution of injunction precluding seaman from pursuing personal injury case in state court was proper as vessel owner's right to limited liability was protected and savings to suitor clause reserved all remedies, not just right to jury trial.

CaseName: Christine Todd Whitman, Administrator Of Environmental Protection Agency, Et Al. V. American Trucking Associations, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Finding that EPA could not consider implementation costs in setting NAAQS was affirmed, but action was remanded since EPA's interpretation of the CAA section relating to implementation of revised ozone NAAQS was unreasonable.

CaseName: Legal Services Corporation V. Carmen Velazquez, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Funding provision that limited arguments legal services attorneys were allowed to make on behalf of indigent welfare claimants violated First Amendment by regulating private speech and insulating federal law from legitimate judicial challenge.

CaseName: Traffix Devices, Inc. V. Marketing Displays, Inc.
CaseSummary: Regardless of acquired secondary meaning, patent claims and prior patent infringement litigation concerning dual-spring sign stand mechanism indicated that mechanism was functional, thus precluding trade dress protection.

CaseName: Robert Shaw, Et Al.  V. Kevin Murphy
CaseSummary: Judgment upholding inmate's First Amendment claim was reversed and remanded, since inmates did not possess a First Amendment right to provide legal assistance that enhanced the protections available under the Turner test.

CaseName: Cooper Industries, Inc. V. Leatherman Tool Group, Inc.
CaseSummary: Court of appeal's affirmation of a punitive damages award was vacated and remanded, since it should have applied a de novo standard of review when passing on the district court's determination of the constitutionality of the award.

CaseName: Bartnicki Et Al. V. Vopper, Aka Williams, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where unknown person surreptitiously intercepted a telephone conversation on a matter of public concern and the media published the content, federal and state wiretapping statutes punishing the publishers violated First Amendment.

CaseName: The Wharf (Holdings) Limited, Et Al. V. United International Holdings, Inc. Et Al.
CaseSummary: An oral agreement to give an option to buy stock while secretly intending never to honor that option was found to be a violation of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934's prohibition of deceptive devices.

CaseName: Norfolk Shipbuilding & Drydock Corporation V. Celestine Garris, Administratrix Of The Estate Of Christopher Garris, Deceased
CaseSummary: The maritime cause of action established for unseaworthiness was equally available for negligence. Mother's negligence action for wrongful death of son was not preempted by federal maritime statutes.

CaseName: Sharon B. Pollard V. E. I. Du Pont De Nemours & Company
CaseSummary: In former employee's hostile work environment action, the statutory damages cap was inapplicable to front pay because front pay was not an element of compensatory damages within the meaning of the federal statute.

CaseName: Tuan Anh Nguyen And Joseph Boulais V. Immigration And Naturalization Service
CaseSummary: Where different requirements for citizenship depending upon which unwed parent was a citizen was justified by two important governmental objectives and the means employed were substantially related to those objectives, equal protection was satisfied.

CaseName: Good News Club, Et Al. V. Milford Central School
CaseSummary: When public school denied club access to the school's limited public forum on the ground that the club was religious in nature, it discriminated against the club because of its religious viewpoint in violation of the Free Speech Clause.

CaseName: Donald Saucier V. Elliot M. Katz And In Defense Of Animals
CaseSummary: In an excessive force case, an officer was entitled to qualified immunity because the officer's conduct in arresting a protestor at a public gathering did not violate a clearly established constitutional right.

CaseName: United States And Department Of Agriculture V. United Foods, Inc.
CaseSummary: Mandatory advertising assessments imposed on mushroom producers and handlers under the Mushroom Promotion, Research, and Consumer Information Act violated the First Amendment; they were not part of a broad regulatory scheme.

CaseName: Federal Election Commission V. Colorado Republican Federal Campaign Committee
CaseSummary: Political reality established that limits on political party's expenditures coordinated with candidate were constitutional, as reasonable restriction to minimize circumvention of contribution limits.

CaseName: New York Times Company, Inc., Et Al. V. Jonathan Tasini, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Print and electronic publishers infringed freelance authors' copyrights by placing authors' articles in electronic databases that allowed reproducing and distributing articles standing alone and not as part of the printed collective work.

CaseName: Trw Inc. V. Adelaide Andrews
CaseSummary: The Court reversed the decision that the Fair Credit Reporting Act incorporated a discovery rule where such interpretation of § 1681p would have distorted its text and made the exception to the rule superfluous in all but the most unusual situations.

CaseName: J. E. M. Ag Supply, Inc., Dba Farm Advantage, Inc., Et Al. V. Pioneer Hi-bred International, Inc.
