CaseSummary: In patent infringement suit regarding hybrid corn seed patents, utility patents could be issued for plants; Plant Patent Act of 1930 and Plant Variety Protection Act did not provide the exclusive means of protecting new varieties of plants.

CaseName: Great-west Life & Annuity Insurance Company, Et Al. V. Janette Knudson And Eric Knudson
CaseSummary: Insurance companies' action seeking reimbursement of benefits paid to beneficiaries under an ERISA plan was not authorized under ERISA's catch-all provision authorizing equitable relief because the claim was for a legal remedy, i.e. money damages.

CaseName: Caren Cronk Thomas And Windy City Hemp Development Board V. Chicago Park District
CaseSummary: Where the licensing scheme was not based on subject-matter censorship but rather content-neutral time, place, and manner regulation of the use of a public forum, the ordinance was constitutional.

CaseName: Jo Anne B. Barnhart, Commissioner Of Social Security V. Sigmon Coal Company, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Coal Act did not permit assignment of health care benefits for retired miners to coal companies as successors in interest of out-of-business operator, since companies were not related to operator under statutory definition.

CaseName: Cornelius P. Young, Et Ux. V. United States
CaseSummary: Bankruptcy court properly concluded that taxpayers' 1992 tax debt had not been discharged, since the three-year lookback period was tolled during the pendency of the taxpayers' prior bankruptcy petition.

CaseName: John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General, Et Al. V. The Free Speech Coalition Et Al.
CaseSummary: Ban on virtual child pornography was unconstitutionally overbroad since it proscribed speech which was neither child pornography nor obscene and thus abridged freedom to engage in substantial amount of lawful speech.

CaseName: Tommy G. Thompson, Secretary Of Health And Human Services, Et Al. V. Western States Medical Center Et Al.
CaseSummary: Ban on advertising compounded drugs unconstitutionally restricted pharmacies' commercial speech, since government failed to demonstrate that ban was not more extensive than necessary to prevent large-scale manufacturing of unapproved drugs

CaseName: City Of Los Angeles V. Alameda Books, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: In overcoming summary judgment against it, city could reasonably rely on a study it conducted some years before enacting an ordinance to demonstrate that a ban on multiple-use adult establishments served its interest in reducing crime.

CaseName: Verizon Communications Inc., Et Al. V. Federal Communications Commission, Et Al.
CaseSummary: In dispute regarding FCC's authority to regulate relationship between incumbents and entrants in local-exchange market, FCC's forward-looking cost methodology and additional combination rules were authorized by Telecommunications Act of 1996.

CaseName: John Ashcroft, Attorney General V. American Civil Liberties Union, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The United States Supreme Court held the Child Online Protection Act's reliance on community standards to identify material harmful to minors did not by itself render it substantially overbroad for purposes of the First Amendment.

CaseName: Festo Corporation V. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo Kabushiki Co., Ltd., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A judgment of the court of appeals was reversed because under prosecution history estoppel and the doctrine of equivalents, the patentee should have been allowed to show that its narrowing amendments did not surrender the equivalents at issue.

CaseName: Securities And Exchange Commission V. Charles Zandford
CaseSummary: In SEC's civil securities fraud case, stockbroker's breaches of fiduciary duty were "in connection with" securities sales because the securities transactions and breaches of fiduciary duty coincided.

CaseName: Watchtower Bible And Tract Society Of New York, Inc., Et Al. V. Village Of Stratton Et Al.
CaseSummary: A village ordinance, requiring canvassers to obtain a permit prior to engaging in the door-to-door advocacy of religious and political causes and to display the permit upon demand, violated the First Amendment.

CaseName: Kay Barnes, Etc., Et Al. V. Jeffrey Gorman
CaseSummary: Applying a contract-law analogy for damages, United States Supreme Court reversed court of appeals' decision upholding award of punitive damages against police board and officer in arrestee's claims under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.

CaseName: Warren Christopher, Former Secretary Of State, Et Al. V. Jennifer K. Harbury
CaseSummary: Claim that concealment of information caused widow to forego judicial relief to prevent foreign dissident's death failed to allege denial of access to courts, since underlying cause of action was not identified and relief was otherwise available.

CaseName: Susan Tave Zelman, Superintendent Of Public Instruction Of Ohio, Et Al. V. Doris Simmons-harris Et Al.
CaseSummary: Ohio's Pilot Project Scholarship Program, designed to provide educational choices to families in Cleveland, did not violate the Establishment Clause as it was a program of true private choice and was entirely neutral towards religion.

CaseName: Republican Party Of Minnesota, Et Al. V. Suzanne White, Chairperson, Minnesota Board Of Judicial Standards, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state's canon of judicial conduct, prohibiting candidates for judicial election from announcing their views on disputed legal and political issues, violated the First Amendment.

CaseName: Mathias V. Worldcom Techs.
Yellow Transportation, Inc. V. Michigan, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Interstate Commerce Commission's interpretation of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act was consistent with statutory language and reasonably resolved any ambiguity, so the state supreme court erred in declining to enforce it.

CaseName: Karen Howsam, Etc. V. Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc.
CaseSummary: The question of whether an arbitration was barred by the time limit set out in a securities dealers rule required resolution by the arbitrator, since the issue did not raise a substantive question of arbitrability requiring judicial resolution.

CaseName: Borden Ranch Partnership And Angelo K. Tsakopoulos V. United States Army Corps Of Engineers And Environmental Protection Agency
Pierce County, Washington V. Ignacio Guillen, Legal Guardian Of Jennifer Guillen And Alma Guillen, Minors, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A statute granting privilege to information gathered for a federal highway safety program, aimed at improving commerce channel safety and increasing protection for interstate commerce instrumentalities, was within Congress' Commerce Clause power.

CaseName: Eric Eldred, Et Al. V. John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General
CaseSummary: The Copyright Term Extension Act, which enlarged the duration of copyrights by 20 years, did not violate the First Amendment or the Copyright and Patent Clause of the United States Constitution.

CaseName: Federal Communications Commission V. Nextwave Personal Communications Inc. Et Al.
CaseSummary: FCC's cancellations of broadband spectrum licenses upon bankruptcy debtors' failure to make installment payments for the licenses was unlawful, since the cancellations revoked the licenses solely for nonpayment of debts dischargeable in bankruptcy.

CaseName: Scheidler V. National Organization For Women, Inc.
CaseSummary: Activities of abortion opponents in depriving abortion supporters of their right to legal abortions did not constitute predicate racketeering acts of extortion required for a RICO violation, since opponents obtained nothing of value from supporters.

CaseName: Victor Moseley And Cathy Moseley, Dba Victor's Little Secret V. V Secret Catalogue, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where owners of a famous trademark asserted a dilution claim against owners of a single lingerie store using a non-identical name, the trademark owners were required to show actual dilution, rather than a likelihood of dilution.

CaseName: Cook County, Illinois V. United States Ex Rel. Janet Chandler
CaseSummary: The statute providing liability for submitting false claims to the federal government applied to a county, since the treble damages provision of the statute was remedial as well as punitive and did not impliedly repeal county liability.

CaseName: Norfolk & Western Railway Company V. Freeman Ayers Et Al.
CaseSummary: Mental anguish damages resulting from the fear of developing cancer were recoverable under the FELA by railroad workers suffering from the actionable injury asbestosis caused by work-related exposure to asbestos.

CaseName: A. Elliott Archer, Et Ux. V. Arlene L. Warner
CaseSummary: Where creditors and debtors settled a fraud suit and the debtors defaulted on the resulting promissory note, the settlement did not bar the creditors from alleging that the debt was nondischargeable because it was for money obtained by fraud.

CaseName: Virginia V. Barry Elton Black, Richard J. Elliott, And Jonathan O'mara
CaseSummary: Statutory prohibition of cross-burning with the intent to intimidate did not violate respondents' right to freedom of speech, since the statute banned intentional intimidating conduct rather than expression.

CaseName: Pacificare Health Systems, Inc., Et Al. V. Jeffrey Book Et Al.
CaseSummary: Judgment denying managed-health-care organizations' request to compel arbitration of the RICO claims was reversed and remanded where the application of the disputed language in the arbitration agreements to the physicians' RICO claims was in doubt.

CaseName: State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company V. Inez Preece Campbell And Matthew C. Barneck, Special Administrator And Personal Representative Of The Estate Of Curtis B. Campbell
CaseSummary: Where insureds were awarded $ 1 million in compensatory damages for an insurer's bad faith refusal to settle meritorious claims against the insureds, a punitive damages award of $ 145 million was arbitrary and excessive, and thus unconstitutional.

CaseName: Illinois Ex Rel. Lisa Madigan, Attorney General Of Illinois V. Telemarketing Associates, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: While fundraising corporations' failure to disclose the high percentage of donations retained as fundraising costs was protected by freedom of speech, the corporations could be liable for making misrepresentations of how donations would be used.

CaseName: Pharmaceutical Research And Manufacturers Of America V. Peter E. Walsh, Acting Commissioner, Maine Department Of Human Services, Et Al.
CaseSummary: In nonresident drug manufacturers association's challenge to Maine's Medicaid prescription drug program's prior authorization requirement, the association was not entitled to a preliminary injunction based upon preemption and Commerce Clause claims.

CaseName: The Black & Decker Disability Plan V. Kenneth L. Nord
CaseSummary: The ERISA requirement for a full and fair consideration of a disability claim did not include any requirement that the opinions of treating physicians be given controlling weight under the treating physician rule applied in social security cases.

CaseName: Dastar Corporation V. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where a producer marketed a video which copied a public domain television series, without acknowledging the series, the producer properly designated the origin of the tangible video product and was not required to identify the origin of the ideas.

CaseName: Hillside Dairy Inc., A&a Dairy, L&s Dairy, And Milky Way Farms V. William J. Lyons, Jr., Secretary, California Department Of Food And Agriculture, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Lower court erred in rejecting the out-of-state dairy producers' Commerce Clause challenge because the federal statute authorizing California's milk compositional and labeling laws did not expressly authorize its pricing and pooling laws.

CaseName: Desert Palace, Inc., Dba Caesars Palace Hotel & Casino V. Catharina F. Costa
CaseSummary: In an employee's Title VII sex discrimination suit, the employee did not need to present direct evidence of discrimination in order to obtain a mixed-motive jury instruction.

CaseName: Michael Fitzgerald, Treasurer Of Iowa V. Racing Association Of Central Iowa Et Al.
CaseSummary: Judgment that found State's tax laws violated Equal Protection Clause was reversed and remanded where facts did not preclude an inference that reason for different tax rates was to help riverboat industry, and there was a rational basis for the laws.

CaseName: Virginia V. Kevin Lamont Hicks
CaseSummary: Decision that a housing development's trespass policy was unconstitutionally overbroad was reversed and remanded because the policy applied to everyone who entered the streets of the development, not just to those who sought to engage in expression.

CaseName: William Overton, Director, Michigan Department Of Corrections, Et Al. V. Michelle Bazzetta Et Al.
CaseSummary: State prison regulations restricting non-contact prisoner visitation from children and former inmates, and banning visits to prisoners with substance abuse violations, did not constitute denials of substantive due process or freedom of association.

CaseName: Federal Election Commission V. Christine Beaumont Et Al.
CaseSummary: Ban on direct corporate contributions with regard to federal elections was properly applied to nonprofit advocacy corporation and did not unconstitutionally restrict the corporation's ability to engage in effective speech and political association.

CaseName: United States, Et Al. V. American Library Association, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because public libraries' use of Internet filtering software did not violate patrons' First Amendment rights, the Children's Internet Protection Act did not induce libraries to violate the Constitution and was a valid exercise of spending power.

CaseName: Green Tree Financial Corp., Nka Conseco Finance Corp. V. Lynn W. Bazzle Et Al., In A Representative Capacity On Behalf Of A Class And For All Others Similarly Situated, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where the question of whether arbitration contracts forbade class arbitration was a question for an arbitrator to decide, and the parties had not received an arbitrator's decision on that question, the judgment was vacated and remanded.

CaseName: John Geddes Lawrence And Tyron Garner V. Texas
CaseSummary: A decision upholding a Texas statute that made it a crime for two persons of the same sex to engage in certain intimate sexual conduct was overruled because petitioners were entitled to respect for their private lives.

CaseName: Mitch Mcconnell, United States Senator, Et Al. V. Federal Election Commission, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Restrictions on soft money contributions to political campaigns and on issue advertising did not facially violate the First Amendment; recordkeeping requirements concerning political advertising also were valid.

CaseName: Securities And Exchange Commission V. Charles E. Edwards
CaseSummary: A payphone sale-and-leaseback scheme promising a fixed rate of return rather than a variable return could be an investment contract, and thus a security, subject to the federal securities laws.

CaseName: Verizon Communications Inc. V. Law Offices Of Curtis V. Trinko, Llp
CaseSummary: A local telephone service customer's complaint alleging breach of the incumbent local exchange carrier's duty under the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to share its network with competitors failed to state a claim under the Sherman Act.

CaseName: Andrew J. Kontrick V. Robert A. Ryan
CaseSummary: A bankruptcy debtor forfeited his right to challenge the timeliness of a creditor's admittedly untimely objection to discharge since the debtor did not raise the issue prior to a decision on the merits in the creditor's favor.

CaseName: Alaska Department Of Environmental Conservation V. Environmental Protection Agency Et Al.
CaseSummary: EPA had supervisory authority over the reasonableness of a state permitting agency's determination of best available air pollution control technology, and inconsistent findings of economic feasibility did not support the agency's determination.

CaseName: Jeff Groh V. Joseph R. Ramirez Et Al.
CaseSummary: Lower court properly concluded that a warrant that failed to describe the type of evidence sought in a search of the individuals' home was unconstitutional and that the federal agent responsible for the search was not entitled to qualified immunity.

CaseName: Olympic Airways V. Rubina Husain, Individually And As Personal Representative Of The Estate Of Abid M. Hanson, Deceased, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Flight attendant's refusal to move passenger farther away from smoking section constituted an accident under the Warsaw Convention because it was an unusual or unexpected event and it was a link in the chain of causes that led to passenger's death.

CaseName: Gary Locke, Governor Of Washington, Et Al. V. Joshua Davey
CaseSummary: Prohibition against the use of state scholarship funds to pursue a theology degree was not unconstitutional since it was not hostile to religion, but rather reflected the state's substantial interest against the establishment of religion.

CaseName: United States Postal Service V. Flamingo Industries (Usa) Ltd. Et Al.
CaseSummary: The United States Postal Service was not subject to antitrust liability, because the United States was not a "person" under the Sherman Act, and the Postal Service was not a separate antitrust person from the United States.

CaseName: Raymond B. Yates, M.d., P.c. Profit Sharing Plan, And Raymond B. Yates, Trustee V. William T. Hendon, Trustee
CaseSummary: Where a bankruptcy trustee sought to avoid a preferential transfer by a professional corporation's owner to a profit sharing plan, the working owner could qualify as a participant in the plan covered by ERISA.

CaseName: South Florida Water Management District V. Miccosukee Tribe Of Indians Et Al.
CaseSummary: In a dispute regarding whether a pump station, which emptied water from a canal into a water conservation area (WCA), required a discharge permit, a factual dispute existed as to whether the canal and the WCA were distinct water bodies.

CaseName: Bedroc Limited, Llc, And Western Elite, Inc. V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where sand and gravel in Nevada were essentially worthless at the time of enactment of a statutory reservation of valuable minerals to the government in Nevada land grants, the sand and gravel were not valuable minerals subject to the reservation.

CaseName: Household Credit Services, Inc. And Mbna America Bank, N. A. V. Sharon R. Pfennig
CaseSummary: Where a credit card holder alleged that petitioners violated TILA by failing to classify over-limit fees as "finance charges," the Federal Reserve Board's decision to exclude over-limit fees from the term "finance charge" was reasonable.

CaseName: Lee M. Till, Et Ux. V. Scs Credit Corporation
CaseSummary: The proper interest rate to be applied to secured claims in a Chapter 13 debt adjustment plan was the national prime rate as adjusted for the specific risks of the debtors, without regard to the rate set out in the parties' security agreement.

CaseName: Central Laborers' Pension Fund V. Thomas E. Heinz Et Al.
CaseSummary: Pension fund's amendment expanding a definition of disqualifying work to include supervisory construction work violated ERISA's anti-cutback rule as it effectively undercut the retirees' reasonable reliance on the plan's terms in planning retirement.

CaseName: Department Of Transportation, Et Al. V. Public Citizen Et Al.
CaseSummary: In issuing rules concerning safety regulation of Mexican motor carriers, the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration did not violate NEPA by not considering the environmental effect of an increase in cross-border operations of the motor carriers.

CaseName: City Of Littleton, Colorado V. Z. J. Gifts D-4, L. L. C., A Limited Liability Company, Dba Christal's
CaseSummary: Where adult business license requirements were based on objective, nondiscretionary criteria unrelated to the content of expressive materials, no expedited judicial review was required to prevent undue delay in resolving protected speech issues.

CaseName: Gale Norton, Secretary Of The Interior, Et Al. V. Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance Et Al.
CaseSummary: BLM's alleged violation of a mandate to manage wilderness study areas so as not to impair their suitability for wilderness protection was not subject to judicial review under the APA as the statute did not mandate how that goal was to be achieved.

CaseName: Pennsylvania State Police V. Nancy Drew Suders
CaseSummary: Where an employee alleged a constructive discharge based on sexual harassment by supervisors, employer liability was subject to the defense that the employee failed to avail herself of the employer's effective process for remedying the harassment.

CaseName: F. Hoffmann-la Roche Ltd, Et Al. V. Empagran S.a. Et Al.
CaseSummary: Domestic-injury exception of the Foreign Trade Antitrust Improvements Act did not apply to the vitamin manufacturers' price fixing activity that was in significant part foreign, had the requisite domestic effect, and had independent foreign effects.

CaseName: John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General V. American Civil Liberties Union Et Al.
CaseSummary: Preliminary injunctive relief was warranted to bar enforcement of a statute requiring age verification before posting Internet material harmful to minors, since filtering software was a plausible less restrictive alternative for protecting minors.

CaseName: Jose Francisco Sosa V. Humberto Alvarez-machain Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where a Mexican alien was abducted and delivered to the United States for prosecution, government liability under the FTCA was barred since the harm occurred in Mexico and the brief illegal detention of the alien did not violate the law of nations.

CaseName: Norfolk Southern Railway Company V. James N. Kirby, Pty Ltd., Dba Kirby Engineering, And Allianz Australia Insurance Limited
CaseSummary: Where a freight forwarder hired a shipper which in turn hired a railroad company, the limitations of liability in the bills of lading issued by the forwarder and the shipper limited the company's liability to the cargo owner for loss of the cargo.

CaseName: Koons Buick Pontiac Gmc, Inc. V. Bradley Nigh
CaseSummary: A $1,000 cap on Truth in Lending Act awards for loans secured with personal property still applied even after a 1995 amendment raising the awards for closed-end mortgages which arguably could have limited the cap to leases and not loans.

CaseName: Kp Permanent Make-up, Inc. V. Lasting Impression I, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A seller of cosmetics which used the term "microcolor" was not required to show the unlikelihood of consumer confusion to support its fair use defense to a claim of infringement of a competitor's incontestable trademark for "micro colors."

CaseName: Cooper Industries, Inc. V. Aviall Services, Inc.
CaseSummary: Property purchaser could not obtain CERCLA contribution from seller following voluntary cleanup of contaminated site because purchaser had not been sued under CERCLA; contribution could only be sought "during or following" specified civil actions.

CaseName: Willard Stewart V. Dutra Construction Company
CaseSummary: Where a dredge for removing silt from the ocean floor navigated short distances by manipulating its anchors and cables, for purposes of the LHWCA the dredge was a vessel under 1 U.S.C.S. § 3 since it was a watercraft practically capable of maritime transportation, regardless of whether the dredge was in motion or primarily used for transportation.

CaseName: George J. Tenet, Individually, Porter J. Goss, Director Of Central Intelligence And Director Of The Central Intelligence Agency, And United States V. John Doe, Et Ux.
CaseSummary: Where former espionage agents sought promised financial assistance from the government, the state secrets privilege did not provide the absolute protection required for nondisclosure of the clandestine espionage relationship, and actions premised upon such a relationship were barred regardless of the theory of recovery.

CaseName: Roderick Jackson V. Birmingham Board Of Education
CaseSummary: Retaliation for a high school teacher's advocacy of the rights of the girls' basketball team based on unequal funding and unequal access to athletic equipment and facilities could have been discrimination on the basis of sex in violation of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, 20 U.S.C.S. § 1681 et seq.

CaseName: Richard Gerald Rousey, Et Ux. V. Jill R. Jacoway
CaseSummary: Husband and wife who owned Individual Retirement Accounts (IRA) could exempt IRA assets from Chapter 7 bankruptcy estate because IRAs fulfilled both of the 11 U.S.C.S. § 522(d)(10)(E) requirements at issue; the IRAs conferred a right to receive payment "on account of age" and were "similar plans or contracts" to those enumerated in § 522(d)(10)(E).

CaseName: Dura Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Et Al. V. Michael Broudo Et Al.
CaseSummary: An allegation in a securities fraud complaint that the price of a corporation's stock on the date of purchase was artificially inflated because of a misrepresentation was insufficient by itself to establish the loss causation required by 15 U.S.C.S. § 78u-4(b)(4), since other factors may have contributed to any later decline in the stock price.

CaseName: Jennifer M. Granholm, Governor Of Michigan, Et Al. V. Eleanor Heald, Et Al.
CaseSummary: State laws which allowed in-state wineries to make direct sales to customers but precluded out-of-state wineries from making such sales discriminated against interstate commerce in violation of U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 3, and states' authority to regulate liquor imports under U.S. Const. amend XXI, § 2, did not authorize such discrimination.

CaseName: Mike Johanns, Secretary Of Agriculture, Et Al., V. Livestock Marketing Association Et Al.
CaseSummary: The message set out in the beef promotions pursuant to the Beef Promotion and Research Act of 1985, 7 U.S.C.S. § 2901 et seq., was from beginning to end a message established by the federal government; cattle farmer associations had no First Amendment right not to fund government speech.

CaseName: Michael Clingman, Secretary, Oklahoma State Election Board, Et Al. V. Andrea L. Beaver Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where Okla. Stat. Ann. tit. 26, § 1-104 only permitted party members and registered Independents to vote in the party's primary election, the semiclosed primary system only minimally burdened associational rights of members of other parties and the burden was justified by the state's regulatory interests in preserving party identity.

CaseName: Jon B. Cutter, Et Al. V. Reginald Wilkinson, Director, Ohio Department Of Rehabilitation And Correction, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Prison officials were not entitled to dismissal of claim by inmates who alleged a failure to accommodate their exercise of nonmainstream religions; § 3 of the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000cc-1, on its face, qualified as a permissible accommodation not barred by U.S. Const. amend. I's Establishment Clause.

CaseName: Ulysses Tory, Et Al. V. Johnnie L. Cochran, Jr.
CaseSummary: Where a permanent injunction was imposed in an attorney's state law defamation action, the attorney's death did not moot the case as the injunction was still valid under state law and burdened petitioners' First Amendment rights; but the injunction's underlying rationale was gone, so, in its current form, it was an impermissible prior restraint.

CaseName: Merck Kgaa V. Integra Lifesciences I, Ltd., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Drug company's use of patented tripeptide sequence in preclinical studies was protected under 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(e)(1) at least as long as there was a reasonable basis to believe that the compound tested could be subject of FDA submission and that experiments would produce types of information relevant to a drug application under 21 U.S.C.S. § 355.

CaseName: American Trucking Associations, Inc. And Usf Holland, Inc. V. Michigan Public Service Commission Et Al.
CaseSummary: Michigan's flat annual fee on trucks engaged in intrastate commercial hauling under Mich. Comp. Laws Ann. § 478.2(1) (2002), which did not seek to tax a share of interstate transactions that focused upon local activity, and which was assessed evenhandedly, did not burden or discriminate against interstate commerce or violate Commerce Clause.

CaseName: Francis A. Orff, Et Al. V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: 43 U.S.C.S. § 390uu did not waive immunity from suits directly against the United States, as opposed to joinder of the United States as a necessary party defendant to permit a complete adjudication of rights under a reclamation contract. Where petitioners sought to sue the United States alone, § 390uu did not waive immunity from petitioners' suit.

CaseName: Thomas Van Orden V. Rick Perry, In His Official Capacity As Governor Of Texas And Chairman, State Preservation Board, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A state's display of the Ten Commandments on its state capitol grounds had a dual significance, partaking of both religion and government, and did not violate the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. The display could be distinguished from displays in elementary school classrooms and prayer in public schools.

CaseName: Mccreary County, Kentucky, Et Al. V. American Civil Liberties Union Of Kentucky Et Al.
CaseSummary: District court properly granted preliminary injunction enjoining counties from displaying Ten Commandments in courthouses; determination of counties' purpose was sound basis for ruling that displays violated U.S. Const. amend. I's Establishment Clause, and history of exhibits was properly considered in evaluating counties' claim of secular purpose.

CaseName: Metro-goldwyn-mayer Studios, Inc., Et Al. V. Grokster, Ltd., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Software distributors could be found liable for contributory copyright infringement regardless of the software's lawful uses, since the distributors knew that their software was used primarily to download copyrighted works and the evidence clearly indicated that the distributors intended that the software be used for copyright infringement

CaseName: United States V. Joseph Olson, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Although state law provided liability for state and municipal entities for negligence in uniquely governmental activities such as the federal government's mine inspection, the FTCA only waived sovereign immunity to the extent a private person would be liable but waiver could be premised on like functions performed by private persons.

CaseName: Volvo Trucks North America, Inc. V. Reeder-simco Gmc, Inc.
CaseSummary: Where a truck dealer asserted that a manufacturer granted greater wholesale price concessions to other dealers for purposes of competitive bidding on truck sales, absent actual competition with a favored dealer of the manufacturer, the dealer was unable to show the competitive injury required under the Robinson-Patman Price Discrimination Act.

CaseName: Kelly A. Ayotte, Attorney General Of New Hampshire V. Planned Parenthood Of Northern New England, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Even though the Parental Notification Prior to Abortion Act, N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. §§ 132:24-132:28 (Supp. 2004), was unconstitutional in applications that subjected minors to significant health risks, the proper remedy was a declaratory judgment and enjoining the statute's unconstitutional application, not invalidating it entirely.

CaseName: Wisconsin Right To Life, Inc. V. Federal Election Commission
CaseSummary: Where an organization asserted that application of the definition of electioneering communications in the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act to the organization's advertisements was unconstitutional, the U.S. Supreme Court's holding that the definition was facially valid did not preclude the organization's as-applied challenge to the definition.

CaseName: Alberto R. Gonzales, Attorney General, Et Al. V. O Centro Espirita Beneficente Uniao Do Vegetal Et Al.
CaseSummary: The listing of Dimethyltryptamine (DMT) on Schedule I of the Controlled Substance Act did not relieve the Government of the obligation to shoulder its burden under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA), 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000bb et seq., to demonstrate a compelling interest to confiscate hoasca, a sacramental tea containing DMT.

CaseName: Buckeye Check Cashing, Inc. V. John Cardegna Et Al.
CaseSummary: Whether brought in federal or state court, a challenge to the validity of the contract as a whole, and not specifically to the arbitration clause, had to go to the arbitrator, thus, where check cashing customers asserted a check cashing business' contract was usurious, the arbitration clause was enforceable under the Federal Arbitration Act.

CaseName: Barbara Dolan V. United States Postal Service Et Al.
CaseSummary: United States Postal Service's negligently leaving mail on a customer's porch so that it caused the customer to slip and fall did not fall under the Federal Tort Claims Act's exception to waiver of sovereign immunity found in 28 U.S.C.S. § 2680(b) for a loss, miscarriage, or negligent transmission of letters or postal matter.

CaseName: Jenifer Arbaugh V. Y & H Corporation, Dba The Moonlight Cafe
CaseSummary: Where an employee obtained a favorable verdict in an employment discrimination case, but the employer subsequently established that it did not have sufficient employees to be subject to liability under Title VII, the employee-numerosity requirement was not jurisdictional and thus was not subject to the employer's post-trial challenge.

CaseName: Texaco Inc. V. Fouad N. Dagher, Et Al.
CaseSummary: A joint venture between two oil companies which sold gasoline at a single price for both gasoline brands amounted to little more than price setting by a single entity--albeit, within the context of a joint venture--and not a pricing agreement between competing entities with respect to their competing products; it did not violate 15 U.S.C.S. § 1.

CaseName: Joseph Scheidler, Et Al. V. National Organization For Women, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: In an action brought by abortion clinics and a pro-choice organization against pro-life protesters, the United States Supreme Court held that physical violence unrelated to robbery or extortion falls outside the scope of the Hobbs Act, 18 U.S.C.S. § 1951.

CaseName: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Et Al. V. Independent Ink, Inc.
CaseSummary: In all cases involving a tying arrangement, the plaintiff must prove that the defendant has market power in the tying product. An ink manufacturer could not rely on a presumption that an ink jet patent holder possessed sufficient market power to have engaged in illegal tying and monopolization in violation of 15 U.S.C.S. §§ 1, 2.

CaseName: Donald H. Rumsfeld, Secretary Of Defense, Et Al. V. Forum For Academic And Institutional Rights, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Solomon Amendment, 10 U.S.C.S. § 983, which tied federal funding for institutions of higher education with giving military recruiters access equal to that provided to other recruiters, did not violate law schools' First Amendment speech or association rights.

CaseName: Northern Insurance Company Of New York V. Chatham County, Georgia
CaseSummary: Because a county had failed to demonstrate that it was acting as an arm of the State when it operated a drawbridge, the county was not entitled to immunity from an insurer's suit to recover its costs in repairing a boat owned by an insured that was damaged when the drawbridge malfunctioned.

CaseName: Michael Hartman, Frank Kormann, Pierce Mcintosh, Norman Robbins, And Robert Edwards V. William G. Moore, Jr.
CaseSummary: Plaintiff bringing a Bivens action against postal inspectors for allegedly engineering the criminal prosecution of plaintiff in retaliation for the plaintiff exercising his First Amendment rights had to plead and prove the absence of probable cause in order to withstand the inspectors' motion for summary judgment.

CaseName: Joel Sereboff, Et Ux. V. Mid Atlantic Medical Services, Inc.
CaseSummary: Where beneficiaries were injured in an accident and received a settlement in a tort suit against third parties, the fiduciary could sue the beneficiaries for reimbursement of medical expenses paid by the ERISA plan because the fiduciary's action to enforce the plan's "Acts of Third Parties" provision qualified as an equitable remedy.

CaseName: S. D. Warren Company V. Maine Board Of Environmental Protection Et Al.
CaseSummary: Construing "discharge" in accordance with its ordinary or natural meaning, a processing plant owner's operation of a dam to produce hydroelectricity could result in any discharge into navigable waters, and thus, the owner was required to obtain a state certification under § 401 of the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C.S. § 1341.

CaseName: Ebay Inc., Et Al. V. Mercexchange, L. L. C.
CaseSummary: Traditional four-factor test applied by courts of equity when considering whether to award permanent injunctive relief to prevailing plaintiff applied to disputes arising under Patent Act. Where lower courts did not fairly apply traditional principles in deciding patent holder's motion for a permanent injunction, judgment was vacated and remanded

CaseName: Gil Garcetti, Et Al. V. Richard Ceballos
CaseSummary: Where an employee wrote a memorandum alleging that there were inaccuracies in a search warrant affidavit in a pending criminal case, his First Amendment retaliation claim failed because he was not speaking as a citizen for First Amendment purposes since he made the statements pursuant to his official duties as a deputy district attorney.

CaseName: Howard Delivery Service, Inc., Et Al. V. Zurich American Insurance Co.
CaseSummary: Where a bankrupt employer owed workers' compensation insurance premiums to an insurer, the claim for unpaid premiums was not entitled to priority status under 11 U.S.C.S. § 507(a)(5), because, inter alia, the premiums were more appropriately bracketed with premiums paid for other liability insurance rather than employee benefit plan contributions.

CaseName: John A. Rapanos, Et Ux., Et Al. V. United States
CaseSummary: Decisions upholding Army Corps of Engineers' Clean Water Act jurisdiction over dredging and filling wetlands with hydrological connections to adjacent navigable waters were vacated and remanded, as "the waters of the United States" included only relatively permanent, standing or continuously flowing bodies of water forming geographic features.

CaseName: Burlington Northern & Santa Fe Railway Company V. Sheila White
CaseSummary: Where an employee alleged that her employer retaliated against her for complaining about sexual harassment, there was a sufficient evidentiary basis to support the jury's verdict in her favor under Title VII because it was reasonable to conclude that the reassignment of duties and the rescinded suspension without pay were materially adverse.

CaseName: Neil Randall, Et Al. V. William H. Sorrell Et Al.
CaseSummary: Contribution limits of Vt. Stat. Ann. tit. 17, § 2805, were unconstitutional because in their specific details they failed to satisfy the First Amendment's requirement of careful tailoring; i.e., they imposed burdens upon First Amendment interests that (when viewed in light of the statute's legitimate objectives) were disproportionately severe.

CaseName: Jeffrey A. Beard, Secretary, Pennsylvania Department Of Corrections V. Ronald Banks, Individually And On Behalf Of All Others Similarly Situated
CaseSummary: Summary judgment was appropriate finding that a state prison regulation prohibiting certain particularly difficult inmates from having access to newspapers, magazines, and photographs did not violate the First Amendment; evidence that the regulation was necessary to motivate better behavior provided sufficient justification for the policy.

CaseName: Norfolk Southern Railway Company V. Timothy Sorrell
CaseSummary: In a FELA case arising from a railroad employee's accident, Missouri state courts erroneously applied different standards of causation to determine the railroad's negligence under 45 U.S.C.S. § 51 and the employee's contributory negligence under 45 U.S.C.S. § 53. FELA did not depart from the common-law practice of using the same causation standard.

CaseName: Weyerhaeuser Company V. Ross-simmons Hardwood Lumber Company, Inc.
CaseSummary: Where sawmill alleged that competitor bid up price of sawlogs to prevent sawmill from being profitable in violation of 15 U.S.C.S. § 2, bidding up did not by itself establish predatory bidding absent showing that bidding led to below-cost pricing of competitor's logs and that competitor had dangerous probability of recouping bid-up losses.

CaseName: Philip Morris Usa V. Mayola Williams, Personal Representative Of The Estate Of Jesse D. Williams, Deceased
CaseSummary: A punitive damages award against a cigarette manufacturer for harm to nonparties, in a litigation concerning the manufacturer's deceit in minimizing the dangers of smoking, violated constitutional due process, since harm to nonparties could be considered with regard to reprehensibility but not with regard to the extent of punishment.

CaseName: Robert Louis Marrama V. Citizens Bank Of Massachusetts, Et Al.
CaseSummary: 11 U.S.C.S. § 706(d) provided adequate authority for the denial of a bankruptcy debtor's motion to convert his Chapter 7 case to Chapter 13. Neither 11 U.S.C.S. § 706 nor 11 U.S.C.S. § 1307(c) limited the authority of the bankruptcy court to take appropriate action in response to fraudulent conduct by the debtor.

CaseName: Rockwell International Corp., Et Al. V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: An engineer who predicted that pondcrete would be insolid because of a flaw in a piping system did not qualify as an original source under 31 U.S.C.S. § 3730(e)(4) because the insolidity problem was caused by a new foreman's reduction of the cement-to-sludge ratio long after the engineer had left the plant, not a flaw in the piping system.

CaseName: Alicia G. Limtiaco, Attorney General Of Guam V. Felix P. Camacho, Governor Of Guam
CaseSummary: The term "tax valuation" in 48 U.S.C.S. § 1423a most naturally meant the value to which the tax rate was applied because were it otherwise, the modifier "tax" would have had almost no meaning or a meaning inconsistent with ordinary usage. Therefore Guam's indebtedness was limited to 10 percent of its assessed valuation of taxable property.

CaseName: Environmental Defense, Et Al. V. Duke Energy Corporation, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Construing the Clean Air Act's Prevention of Significant Deterioration regulations on "modification" as tracking the New Source Performance Standards definition implicitly invalidated those regulations, thus 42 U.S.C.S. § 7607(b)'s judicial review limits had to be considered on remand in the environmental groups' action against an energy company.

CaseName: Global Crossing Telecommunications, Inc. V. Metrophones Telecommunications, Inc.
CaseSummary: Payphone operator was entitled to sue a long-distance carrier under 47 U.S.C.S. § 207 for violating an FCC regulation requiring the carrier to pay the operator for free payphone calls to access the carrier, since the FCC reasonably found that the carrier's practice in refusing to pay was unreasonable, and thus unlawful under 47 U.S.C.S. § 201(b).

CaseName: Alberto R. Gonzales, Attorney General V. Leroy Carhart, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Lower courts erred in finding the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003, 18 U.S.C.S. § 1531, unconstitutional on its face; the challengers failed to demonstrate that the Act, as a facial matter, was void for vagueness or that it imposed an undue burden on a woman's right to abortion based on its overbreadth or lack of a health exception.

CaseName: United Haulers Association, Inc., Et Al. V. Oneida-herkimer Solid Waste Management Authority, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Counties' flow control ordinances, which required delivery of all solid waste to processing facilities operated by a public entity, did not violate the Commerce Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 3; the ordinances did not discriminate against interstate commerce, as they benefitted a public facility while treating all private businesses the same.

CaseName: Ksr International Co. V. Teleflex Inc. Et Al.
CaseSummary: Competitor of patent licensees did not infringe patent claim for vehicle accelerator pedal assembly with fixed electronic sensor by adding sensor to competitor's system for use with computer-controlled throttles, since mounting sensor on fixed point of pedal, and benefit of doing so, were obvious, and thus claim was invalid under 35 U.S.C.S. § 103.

CaseName: Microsoft Corporation V. At&t Corp.
CaseSummary: Software producer did not infringe a patent for a computer which processed recorded speech, since providing master disks of enabling software, copies of which were made and installed in computers abroad, did not constitute supplying components of the patented invention from the U.S. for combination abroad within the meaning of 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(f).

CaseName: Bell Atlantic Corporation, Et Al. V.william Twombly, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Telephone and Internet service subscribers failed to state a claim against local exchange carriers for violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act, since allegations of parallel anticompetitive conduct by the carriers, in the absence of plausible factual allegations of a preceding agreement, did not preclude identical and reasonable independent conduct.

CaseName: Lilly M. Ledbetter V. The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, Inc.
CaseSummary: The ongoing effects of lower paychecks due to alleged past sex discrimination could not breathe life into prior, uncharged discrimination where an employee brought a Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000e et seq., action, but did not alleged discriminatory conduct within the charging period.

CaseName: Safeco Insurance Company Of America, Et Al. V. Charles Burr, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Liability under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1681n(a) of the FCRA extended to reckless violations, and offering an initial rate for a new insurance policy could be "adverse action" under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1681m(a). However, an applicant whose credit score did not change his rate was not entitled to notice, and a mistaken statutory interpretation was not reckless.

CaseName: Jeffrey H. Beck, Liquidating Trustee Of The Estates Of Crown Vantage, Inc. And Crown Paper Company V. Pace International Union Et Al.
CaseSummary: 29 U.S.C.S. § 1341(b)(3)(A) did not permit merger with a union's plan as a method of terminating the debtors' single-employer defined-benefit pension plan, thus, the Ninth Circuit's judgment, that the debtors' decision to terminate to allow them to retain a reversion of overfunding was a breach of ERISA fiduciary duties, was reversed.

CaseName: United States V. Atlantic Research Corporation
CaseSummary: Lessee that performed work for the federal government at a Department of Defense facility could bring an action under 42 U.S.C.S. § 9607(a) of CERCLA to recover costs of cleaning up contamination at the site; any private party, including a potentially responsible party, could bring a cost recovery action under § 9607(a)(4)(B).

CaseName: The Permanent Mission Of India To The United Nations, Et Al. V. City Of New York, New York
CaseSummary: Because tax liens inhibited one of the quintessential rights of property ownership--the right to convey, it was plain that a lawsuit filed by New York City to establish the validity of tax liens implicated rights in immovable property and thus fell under the 28 U.S.C.S. § 1605(a)(4) exception to the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act of 1976.

CaseName: Credit Suisse Securities (Usa) Llc, Fka Credit Suisse First Boston Llc, Et Al. V. Glen Billing Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where investors asserted antitrust violations under the Sherman Act, Clayton Act, and Robinson-Patman Act against underwriters regarding conduct during IPOs, the complaints were dismissed because the securities laws implicitly precluded the application of the antitrust laws to the conduct alleged due to SEC regulation and clear incompatibility.

CaseName: Tennessee Secondary School Athletic Association V. Brentwood Academy
CaseSummary: First Amendment did not excuse school from abiding by the same anti-recruiting rule that governed the conduct of its sister schools as an athletic association's rule discouraged the sort of conduct that might lead to a variety of harms, any one of which would detract from a high school sports league's ability to operate efficiently and effectively.

CaseName: Tellabs, Inc., Et Al. V. Makor Issues & Rights, Ltd., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A finding that shareholders' allegations in a securities fraud case raised the strong inference of scienter required by 15 U.S.C.S. § 78u-4(b)(2) was erroneous, since there was no consideration of whether the inference of fraudulent intent was a cogent inference that was at least as compelling as any opposing inference of nonfraudulent intent.

CaseName: Deborah Morse, Et Al. V. Joseph Frederick
CaseSummary: School officials did not violate First Amendment by suspending student who refused to take down pro-drug banner at school-sponsored event; the student's § 1983 claim failed because school officials were entitled to take steps to safeguard those entrusted to their care from speech that could reasonably be regarded as encouraging illegal drug use.

CaseName: Federal Election Commission V. Wisconsin Right To Life, Inc.
CaseSummary: Whether a political organization's ads were unconstitutionally barred under the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act was not moot since the dispute was capable of repetition while evading review, and the proscription of the ads which protested a filibuster to delay voting on federal judicial nominees was unconstitutional.

CaseName: Charles Wilkie, Et Al. V. Harvey Frank Robbins
CaseSummary: The affirmance of a denial of summary judgment to Bureau of Land Management officials on a landowner's Fifth Amendment retaliation Bivens claim alleging harassment and intimidation aimed at extracting an easement was reversed because the officials' conduct of trying to induce an easement grant for public use was a legitimate purpose.

CaseName: National Association Of Home Builders, Et Al. V. Defenders Of Wildlife Et Al.
CaseSummary: The ESA requirement to insure no jeopardy to endangered species did not apply to the EPA's approval of a transfer to a state of water quality permitting authority under the CWA, since the no-jeopardy duty only applied to discretionary actions and approval of the permitting transfer was mandatory once the state met the triggering criteria.

CaseName: Leegin Creative Leather Products, Inc. V. Psks, Inc., Dba Kay's Kloset . . . Kay's Shoes
CaseSummary: Where a manufacturer allegedly violated the Sherman Act by entering into agreements with retailers to charge fixed prices, vertical price restraints were to be judged according to the rule of reason, not the per se rule, because, inter alia, procompetitive justifications existed for a manufacturer's use of resale price maintenance.

CaseName: Csx Transportation, Inc. V. Georgia State Board Of Equalization Et Al
CaseSummary: Where a carrier alleged that Georgia's property tax assessment involved discrimination in violation of the Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act (4-R Act), the carrier could challenge Georgia's methods for determining the value of railroad property because the 4-R Act provided for such a challenge.

CaseName: Stoneridge Investment Partners, Llc V. Scientific-atlanta, Inc., Et Al
CaseSummary: The 15 U.S.C.S. § 78j(b) implied private right of action did not extend to aiders and abettors, thus, suppliers' and customers' arrangements that allowed the investors' company to mislead its auditor and issue a misleading financial statement were not actionable and were properly dismissed.

CaseName: New York State Board Of Elections, Et Al. V. Margarita Lopez Torres Et Al
CaseSummary: A preliminary injunction that returned New York to a direct primary election for selecting supreme court justices was reversed because New York State's convention system for selecting supreme court justices, N.Y. Elec. Law §§ 6-106, 6-124 (2007), did not violated the First Amendment rights of potential candidates for justice.

CaseName: Abdus-shahid M. S. Ali V. Federal Bureau Of Prisons Et Al
CaseSummary: A decision that a federal prisoner's claim arising from the loss of his personal property during a prison transfer was barred by 28 U.S.C.S. § 2680(c) was affirmed where the phrase "any other law enforcement officer" evinced clear congressional intent that the statute was not limited to officers acting in a customs or excise capacity.

CaseName: James Larue V. Dewolff, Boberg & Associates, Inc., Et Al
CaseSummary: 29 U.S.C.S. § 1132(a)(2) did not provide remedies only for entire plans, thus, the affirmance of the dismissal of a pension plan participant's claim that the employer breached a fiduciary duty under 29 U.S.C.S. § 1109(a) of ERISA by failing to follow his investment directions was vacated.

CaseName: Hall Street Associates, L.l.c. V. Mattel, Inc
CaseSummary: While the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) allowed parties to tailor many features of arbitration by contract, 9 U.S.C.S. § 9's textual features did not provide for enforcing a contract to expand judicial review following the arbitration. 9 U.S.C.S. §§ 10 and 11 provided exclusive regimes for the review provided by the FAA.

CaseName: Meadwestvaco Corporation, Successor In Interest To The Mead Corporation V. Illinois Department Of Revenue Et Al
CaseSummary: Because the Illinois trial court found the sold business division was not a unitary part of the Ohio taxpayer's business, but the Appellate Court of Illinois' affirmance did not address the "hallmarks" of a unitary relationship (functional integration, centralized management, and economies of scale), its judgment was vacated and remand was ordered.

CaseName: United States V. Michael Williams
CaseSummary: Offers to provide or requests to obtain child pornography were categorically excluded from First Amendment protection; therefore, 18 U.S.C.S. § 2252A(a)(3)(B) which criminalized pandering of child pornography was constitutional and the decision overturning defendant's conviction was reversed.

CaseName: Department Of Revenue Of Kentucky, Et Al. V. George W. Davis, Et Ux
CaseSummary: Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 141.010(10)(c) did not violate the dormant Commerce Clause by including in taxable income interest from only out-of-state municipal bonds, since the tax scheme favored a traditional government function without any differential treatment favoring local entities, and the state properly competed in the bond market.

CaseName: Quanta Computer, Inc., Et Al. V. Lg Electronics, Inc.
CaseSummary: It was error to hold that the doctrine of patent exhaustion did not apply to a patent holder's computer technology patents where nothing in a license agreement limited the licensee's ability to sell its products practicing the patents. Thus, an authorized sale to the computer manufacturers took the products outside the patent monopoly scope.

CaseName: John Bridge, Et Al. V. Phoenix Bond & Indemnity Co. Et Al
CaseSummary: Bidders on county tax liens were not required to show that they relied on alleged misrepresentations to the county by competitors to support a RICO claim based on predicate acts of mail fraud, since reliance by the bidders was not a claim element or a prerequisite to showing causation, and reliance by the county was sufficient.

CaseName: Allison Engine Company, Inc., Et Al. V. United States Ex Rel. Roger L. Sanders And Roger L. Thacker
CaseSummary: Proof of intent to cause false claim to be paid by private entity using Government funds was not sufficient for qui tam claims under 31 U.S.C.S. § 3729(a)(2), (3) of FCA; relator was required to show intent that false statement be material to Government's decision to pay false claim and that conspirators agreed to use statement to achieve this end.

CaseName: Fla. Dep't Of Revenue V. Piccadilly Cafeterias, Inc.
CaseSummary: A debtor could not rely on 11 U.S.C.S. § 1146(a) to avoid a state revenue department's stamp taxes because the debtor had transferred its assets before its Chapter 11 plan was confirmed by the bankruptcy court; 11 U.S.C.S. § 1146(a) did not apply to pre-confirmation transfers.

CaseName: Metro. Life Ins. Co. V. Glenn
CaseSummary: In action under 29 U.S.C.S. § 1132(a)(1)(B), court of appeals properly found that a plan administrator that both evaluated and paid claims under ERISA plan operated under a Firestone "conflict of interest" in making discretionary benefit determinations; conflict was properly weighed as factor in finding abuse of discretion in denial of LTD claim.

CaseName: Exxon Shipping Co. V. Baker
CaseSummary: Assuming that punitive damages were otherwise available against corporate owners of a supertanker based on the recklessness of the supertanker's captain in causing an oil spill, CWA penalties did not bar such damages since compensatory and punitive remedies were not displaced, but the award was excessive since it exceeded the compensatory award.

CaseName: Morgan Stanley Capital Group Inc. V. Public Utility District No. 1 Of Snohomish County, Washington, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Although FERC properly applied the just-and-reasonable presumption, and the modification standard of serious harm to the public interest, to abnormally high electricity rates under contracts which were not initially reviewed, remand to FERC was proper since FERC failed to address fully consumer burden and market manipulation.

CaseName: Davis V. Fec
CaseSummary: 2 U.S.C.S. § 441a-1(a), which raised the individual campaign contribution limit for opponents of candidates whose expenditure of personal funds exceeded a certain amount, violated the First Amendment right to use personal funds for campaign speech. Related disclosure requirements under § 441a-1(b) also were unconstitutional.

CaseName: Donald C. Winter, Secretary Of The Nav., Et Al. V. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: A preliminary injunction was vacated to the extent challenged by the Navy because the balance of equities and the public interest tipped strongly in favor of the Navy. The Navy's need to conduct realistic training with active sonar to respond to the threat posed by enemy submarines plainly outweighed the interests advanced by environmental groups.

CaseName: Lisa Fitzgerald, Et Vir V. Barnstable School Committee Et Al.
CaseSummary: Dismissal of student's § 1983 peer-on-peer sexual harassment suit against a school district was improper. Title IX, 20 U.S.C.S. § 1681, was not meant to be exclusive mechanism for addressing gender discrimination in schools or substitute for § 1983 suits; thus, § 1983 suit based on the U.S. Constitution's Equal Protection Clause remained available.

CaseName: Vicky S. Crawford V. Metropolitan Government Of Nashville And Davidson County, Tennessee
CaseSummary: An employee's conduct in responding to questions during an employer's internal investigation into a sexual harassment claim against a school district's employee relations director was covered by the opposition clause of 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000e-3(a), and thus, the lower court erred in upholding a grant of summary judgment to the employer on that basis.

CaseName: Kari E. Kennedy, Executrix Of The Estate Of William Patrick Kennedy, Deceased V. Plan Administrator For Dupont Savings And Investment Plan Et Al.
CaseSummary: Administrator of employee benefit plan governed by ERISA properly paid benefits to former spouse of decedent, even though spouse's waiver of benefits in divorce decree did not constitute impermissible alienation of benefits, since decedent did not change beneficiary and spouse did not expressly disclaim benefits in accordance with terms of plan.

CaseName: United States V. Eurodif S. A. Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because nuclear utilities gave cash and untracked, unenriched uranium to a French enrichment factory, which then substantially transformed the uranium into enriched uranium, the Commerce Department's treatment of the transaction as the sale of a good under 19 U.S.C.S. § 1673 for antidumping purposes was reasonable; a contrary holding was reversed.

CaseName: Ben Ysursa, Idaho Secretary Of State, Et Al. V. Pocatello Education Association Et Al.
CaseSummary: First Amendment did not confer an affirmative right to use government payrolls to obtain funds for union political activities or prevent a State from deciding its local governments could not provide payroll deductions for such activities, thus, Idaho Code Ann. § 44-2004(2) was not unconstitutional at the local level. The Ninth Circuit was reversed.

CaseName: Pacific Bell Telephone Company, Dba At&t California Et Al. V. Linkline Communications, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Claim of ISPs that providers of digital subscriber line (DSL) service for connecting to the Internet "squeezed" the ISPs' profit margins was not cognizable under 15 U.S.C.S. § 2, since the providers were under no antitrust obligation to sell wholesale DSL service to the ISPs and there was no showing of predatory pricing at the retail level.

CaseName: Pleasant Grove City, Utah Et Al. V. Summum
CaseSummary: Where a religious organization alleged that a city violated the First Amendment by rejecting a request to erect a privately donated monument in a public park, the city's decision was not subject to the Free Speech Clause, because the decision was best viewed as a form of government speech and forum analysis did not apply.

CaseName: Entergy Corporation V. Riverkeeper, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Appellate court erred setting aside regulations adopted by EPA under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1326(b) of CWA; EPA permissibly relied on cost-benefit analysis in setting national performance standards and providing for cost-benefit variances under 40 C.F.R. § 125.94 in relation to minimizing adverse environmental impact at cooling water intake structures.

CaseName: Ministry Of Defense And Support For The Armed Forces Of The Islamic Republic Of Iran V. Dariush Elahi
CaseSummary: Because a judgment creditor received funds from the U.S. in exchange for a waiver under the Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000 as amended by the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002, 28 U.S.C.S. § 1610 note, he relinquished his attachment on another judgment against Iran; the Ninth Circuit's contrary judgment was reversed.

CaseName: Burlington Northern And Santa Fe Railway Company, Et Al. V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: Supplier of pesticides to a distributor and an owner of property which was a portion of a site contaminated by hazardous substances were not jointly and severally liable for remediation costs under CERCLA, since the supplier did not intentionally arrange for disposal of hazardous substances and the owner's liability was capable of apportionment.

CaseName: At&t Corporation V. Noreen Hulteen Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because an employer's pre-Pregnancy Discrimination Act (PDA), 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000e(k), plan was not adopted with discriminatory intent, applying it pre-PDA was not discriminatory; the pension plan, that gave less retirement credit for pregnancy than medical leave generally did not violate the PDA. The Ninth Circuit erred and was reversed.

CaseName: Polar Tankers, Inc. V. City Of Valdez, Alaska
CaseSummary: Valdez, Alaska, Municipal Code § 3.12.020 (2008), violated the Tonnage Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 3, because it taxed no other form of personal property, its amount depended upon a ship's capacity, and it raised revenue for general municipal services; the Alaska Supreme Court's judgment upholding the tax was reversed.

CaseName: The Travelers Indemnity Company, Et Al. V. Pearlie Bailey Et Al.
CaseSummary: Bankruptcy injunction barring actions against insurers of the bankruptcy debtor's asbestos liability applied to preclude claims that the insurers concealed the dangers of asbestos, since the claims clearly related to the insurers' coverage of the asbestos liability and the injunction was not limited to actions based on the debtor's liability.

CaseName: Coeur Alaska, Inc. V. Southeast Alaska Conservation Council Et Al.
CaseSummary: Court of appeals erred when it found that permit Army Corps of Engineers issued to a mining company, which allowed the company to discharge a rock and water mixture into a lake, was invalid because the permit violated standards EPA promulgated under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1316(b). The Corps acted lawfully when it issued the permit under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1344.

CaseName: Atlantic Sounding Co., Inc., Et Al. V. Edgar L. Townsend
CaseSummary: Tugboat crew member who claimed to have been denied maintenance and cure could pursue a claim for punitive damages. Punitive damages were available for willful and wanton disregard of the maintenance and cure obligation as a matter of general maritime law, and 46 U.S.C.S. § 30104 of the Jones Act did not eliminate that remedy.

CaseName: Hemi Group, Llc And Kai Gachupin V. City Of New York, New York
CaseSummary: City failed to allege a RICO violation; an out-of-state vendor's alleged mail and wire fraud by failing to report cigarette sales to the state as required by federal law, which then provided the city with information concerning sales to city residents, was not the direct cause of the harm to the city from lost tax revenue.

CaseName: Citizens United V. Federal Election Commission
CaseSummary: Ban under 2 U.S.C.S. § 441b on corporate independent expenditures for electioneering communications violated the First Amendment, as political speech could not be suppressed on the basis of the speaker's corporate identity. Disclaimer and disclosure provisions under 2 U.S.C.S. §§ 434 and 441d were valid as applied to a film about a candidate.

CaseName: Nrg Power Marketing, Llc, Et Al. V. Maine Public Utilities Commission Et Al.
CaseSummary: Mobile-Sierra doctrine, under which a rate set by a wholesale energy contract was presumed to meet the "just and reasonable" requirement of 16 U.S.C.S. § 824d(a), was not limited to challenges to contract rates brought by contracting parties; the doctrine also applied to challenges by non-contracting third parties.

CaseName: Mac's Shell Service, Inc., Et Al. V. Shell Oil Products Co. Llc Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because termination under the Petroleum Marketing Practices Act meant putting an end to a relationship, and failures to renew meant nonrenewal, gas station franchisees had no constructive termination claims when they continued to operate a franchise, and signing a renewal agreement, even under protest, barred constructive nonrenewal claims.

CaseName: Reed Elsevier, Inc., Et Al., V. Irvin Muchnick Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because 17 U.S.C.S. § 411(a)'s registration requirement was nonjurisdictional, it had not deprived the district court of jurisdiction over unregistered holders' infringement claims, thus, the Second Circuit's holding that there had been no jurisdiction to approve the holders' settlement with publishers was reversed.

CaseName: Jerry N. Jones, Et Al. V. Harris Associates L. P.
CaseSummary: For liability under 15 U.S.C.S. § 80a-35(b), an adviser's fee had to be so disproportionately large that it bore no reasonable relationship to the services rendered and could not have been the product of arm's length bargaining; thus, the Seventh Circuit's rejection of that test was vacated, and mutual fund shareholders' claims were remanded.

CaseName: Graham County Soil And Water Conservation District, Et Al. V. United States Ex Rel. Karen T. Wilson
CaseSummary: "Administrative" reports, audits, or investigations under 31 U.S.C.S. § 3730(e)(4)(A) encompassed disclosures made in state, local, and federal sources, and thus a relator's qui tam action failed under the public disclosure bar to the extent it was based on information in state and county reports investigating flood remediation contracts.

CaseName: United Student Aid Funds, Inc. V. Francisco J. Espinosa
CaseSummary: It was legal error to confirm Chapter 13 debtor's plan, which discharged student loan interest without finding undue hardship in an adversary proceeding, but the confirmation order was enforceable and binding because the creditor, despite not receiving the required service of the order, had notice of the error but did not object or timely appeal.

CaseName: Esther Hui, Et Al. V. Yanira Castaneda, As Personal Representative Of The Estate Of Francisco Castaneda, Et Al.
CaseSummary: 42 U.S.C.S. § 233(a) provided U.S. public health officials absolute immunity from an alien's Bivens suit for inadequate care while in immigration custody because § 233(a)'s reference to 28 U.S.C.S. §§ 1346(b), 2672, did not incorporate all the provisions of FTCA, and FTCA was the sole remedy against the U.S. An order denying dismissal was reversed.

CaseName: Ken L. Salazar, Secretary Of The Interior, Et Al. V. Frank Buono
CaseSummary: A judgment which held a statute that transferred public land on which a Latin cross had been erected as a memorial for fallen World War I soldiers in exchange for private land violated the Establishment Clause was reversed because it took insufficient account of the context in which the statute was enacted and the reasons for its passage.

CaseName: Stolt-nielsen S. A., Et Al. V. Animalfeeds International Corp.
CaseSummary: Where the parties stipulated that an arbitration clause was silent with respect to class arbitration, an arbitration panel exceeded its powers under the Federal Arbitration Act by finding that the clause allowed class arbitration; the differences between bilateral and class arbitration were too great to presume that silence constituted consent.

CaseName: Merck & Co., Inc., Et Al. V. Richard Reynolds Et Al.
CaseSummary: "Discovery" of facts that put investors on "inquiry notice" did not automatically begin 28 U.S.C.S. § 1658(b)'s limitations period, and since scienter was a "fact" and an FDA warning letter and products liability suits showed little if nothing about a drug company's fraudulent intent, a 15 U.S.C.S. § 78j(b) securities fraud suit was timely.

CaseName: Sally L. Conkright, Et Al. V. Paul J. Frommert Et Al.
CaseSummary: After an appellate remand determined that an ERISA plan administrator's interpretation of pension plan benefits for rehired employees was unreasonable, the administrator's second interpretation was improperly reviewed without deference since the administrator's single honest mistake in interpretation was not a basis for denying deference

CaseName: United States V. Robert J. Stevens
CaseSummary: Prohibition of depictions of animal cruelty under 18 U.S.C.S. § 48 was overbroad under U.S. Const. amend. I, since statutory definition of animal cruelty did not even require that depicted conduct be cruel, included depictions of unlawful conduct unrelated to cruelty, and banned depictions of conduct lawful in one state but not in another state.

CaseName: American Needle, Inc. V. National Football League Et Al.
CaseSummary: Agreements among a football league, its teams, and a licensor formed by the teams to license their intellectual property constituted concerted action that was subject to antitrust scrutiny under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1. The teams' decisions to collectively license their separately owned trademarks joined together independent centers of decisionmaking.

CaseName: Mohamed Ali Samantar V. Bashe Abdi Yousuf Et Al.
CaseSummary: FSIA did not apply to the conduct of a former foreign official, as an official was not a "foreign state" within the meaning of 28 U.S.C.S. § 1603; an "agency or instrumentality" of a foreign state was defined in a manner that did not evidence the intent to include individual officials. The common law of foreign sovereign immunity applied instead.

CaseName: State Of Alabama, Et Al., Plaintiffs V. State Of North Carolina.
CaseSummary: Recommendations of a Special Master were appropriate since the host State for a radioactive waste storage facility under an interstate compact was not subject to monetary sanctions, and the obligation of the host State to take appropriate steps to obtain licensing did not require continuing efforts after a compact commission withdrew its funding.

CaseName: Jan Hamilton, Chapter 13 Trustee V. Stephanie Kay Lanning
CaseSummary: "Forward looking" approach could be used in calculating "projected disposable income" (PDI) under 11 U.S.C.S. § 1325(b)(1)(B) as courts had discretion to account for known or virtually certain changes in a debtor's income. Use of Chapter 13 debtor's current income, not an inflated figure due to a prior one-time employer buyout, was affirmed.

CaseName: William G. Schwab V. Nadejda Reilly
CaseSummary: Where a Chapter 7 debtor claimed exemptions in business equipment that equaled the maximum allowed under 11 U.S.C.S. § 522(d) and also equaled the debtor's estimated market value for the equipment, the trustee was not required to object under § 522(l) in order to preserve the estate's right to retain any value beyond the claimed amount.

CaseName: Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General, Et Al. V. Humanitarian Law Project Et Al.
CaseSummary: 18 U.S.C.S. § 2339B, which prohibited material support to foreign terrorist organizations, did not violate the Fifth or First Amendments as applied to U.S. citizens and organizations that wished to facilitate lawful purposes of terrorist groups by providing training in peacefully resolving disputes and in petitioning for relief.

CaseName: Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd. Et Al. V. Regal-beloit Corp. Et Al.
CaseSummary: On a through bill of lading for ocean transport of goods from China and a rail transport within the U.S., the Carmack Amendment, 49 U.S.C.S. § 11706, did not apply since the bill was issued under the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, 46 U.S.C.S. § 30701 note; a Tokyo forum-selection clause was binding and reversal of dismissal was reversed.

CaseName: Monsanto Company, Et Al. V. Geertson Seed Farms Et Al.
CaseSummary: Broad injunction against any deregulation of licensor's genetically altered alfalfa seed pending environmental review was improper since partial deregulation to allow planting in sufficiently limited circumstances would alleviate harm of gene flow to conventional seed, and injunction improperly preempted lawful process of deregulation.

CaseName: Robert Morrison, Et Al. V. National Australia Bank Ltd. Et Al.
CaseSummary: Where foreign shareholders alleged that respondents violated § 10(b) of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5 regarding securities traded on foreign exchanges, dismissal was warranted because § 10(b) applied only to transactions in securities listed on domestic exchanges and domestic transactions in other securities.

CaseName: Bernard L. Bilski And Rand A. Warsaw V. David J. Kappos, Under Secretary Of Commerce For Intellectual Property And Director, Patent And Trademark Office
CaseSummary: While machine-or-transformation test was not the sole test for deciding whether invention was a patent-eligible "process" under 35 U.S.C.S. § 101, patent application was properly denied because petitioners' claims, which concerned hedging or protecting against risk, were not patentable processes because they were attempts to patent abstract ideas.

CaseName: Christian Legal Society Chapter Of The University Of California, Hastings College Of The Law, Aka Hastings Christian Fellowship V. Leo P. Martinez Et Al.
CaseSummary: Because an accept-all-comers policy was a reasonable viewpoint-neutral condition for a student group to be recognized and provided access to the student-organization forum, the Ninth Circuit's ruling upholding it on a First Amendment challenge by a student group who refused membership to those with different sexual orientation beliefs was affirmed.

CaseName: Costco Wholesale Corporation, Petitioner  V. Omega, S.a.
Jason M. Ransom, Petitioner V. Fia Card Services, N.a., Fka Mbna America Bank, N.a.
CaseSummary: Bankruptcy debtor improperly claimed a vehicle ownership expense in calculating disposable income to pay to creditors under 11 U.S.C.S. § 707(b), since the debtor could only deduct the expense if it was applicable to the debtor's financial circumstances, and the debtor made no loan or lease payment on the vehicle to render the expense applicable.

CaseName: Chase Bank Usa, Na., Petitioner V. James A. Mccoy, Individually And On Behalf Of All Others Similarly Situated
CaseSummary: Although 12 C.F.R. § 226.9 was ambiguous as to whether an increase in a credit card's interest rate pursuant to contract term allowing increase in event of default was a change to initially disclosed term that required prior notice, Court deferred to agency's interpretation that notice was not required before implementing term permitting increase.

CaseName: Csx Transportation, Inc., Petitioner V. Alabama Department Of Revenue Et Al.
CaseSummary: It was error to dismiss a lawsuit filed against the Alabama Department of Revenue by an interstate rail carrier claiming that taxes the State imposed on diesel fuel purchased by the carrier violated 49 U.S.C.S. § 11501(b)(4) because interstate motor and water carriers were not required to pay the taxes or paid taxes at a lower rate.

CaseName: Albert Snyder, Petitioner V. Fred W. Phelps, Sr., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Protestors' speech, which involved picketing 1,000 feet from church where funeral was being held for a marine killed in the line of duty, was at a public place on a matter of public concern; thus, speech was entitled to special protection under First Amendment. Such speech could not be restricted simply because it was upsetting or aroused contempt.

CaseName: Matrixx Initiatives, Inc., Et Al., Petitioners V. James Siracusano Et Al.
CaseSummary: In securities fraud suit under Securities Exchange Act of 1934, where a pharmaceutical company allegedly failed to disclose reports of adverse events associated with a product, investors adequately pleaded materiality and scienter because, inter alia, an allegation of statistical significance was not required to establish materiality or scienter.

CaseName: At&t Mobility Llc, Petitioner V. Vincent Concepcion
CaseSummary: Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) preempted a California rule under which class arbitration waivers in consumer contracts were held unconscionable under certain circumstances; the California rule could not be applied under the 9 U.S.C.S. § 2 saving clause. Requiring the availability of class arbitration was inconsistent with the FAA.

CaseName: Cigna Corporation, Et Al., Petitioners V. Janice C. Amara, Et Al., Individually And On Behalf Of All Others Similarly Situated
CaseSummary: Pension plan was improperly reformed by a district court based on misleading disclosures since 29 U.S.C.S. § 1132(a)(1)(B) provided for enforcement and not changing ERISA plan terms, but reformation appeared to be otherwise available since § 1132(a)(3) authorized appropriate equitable relief which reformation essentially provided.

CaseName: Global-tech Appliances, Inc., Et Al., Petitioners V. Seb S.a.
CaseSummary: Induced infringement under 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(b) required knowledge that the induced acts constituted patent infringement, and because a competitor's designers copied all but the cosmetic features of a patent holder's product based on an overseas model, knowing it was for U.S. sales but had no patent markings, a verdict of liability was affirmed.

CaseName: John D. Ashcroft, Petitioner V. Abdullah Al-kidd
