CaseSummary: Because an objectively reasonable arrest and detention of a material witness under 18 U.S.C.S. § 3144, pursuant to a validly obtained warrant, could not be challenged under the Fourth Amendment as unconstitutional on the basis of allegations that the arresting authority had an improper motive, a former Attorney General was entitled to immunity.

CaseName: Board Of Trustees Of The Leland Stanford Junior University, Petitioner V. Roche Molecular Systems, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: "Invention of the contractor" under 35 U.S.C.S. § 201(e) meant one owned by the contractor, which did not automatically include one made by a federal contractor university's professor, thus, the professor's assignment of his rights to a research company made the company a co-owner and that interest was not extinguished by the Bayh-Dole Act.

CaseName: Microsoft Corporation, Petitioner V. I4i  Limited Partnership Et Al.
CaseSummary: Invalidity of patent for method of editing computer documents required clear and convincing evidence since presumption of patent validity in 35 U.S.C.S. § 282 had settled common-law meaning requiring clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption, and evidence not considered by examiner did not alter standard to preponderance of evidence.

CaseName: Talk America, Petitioner V. Michigan Bell Telephone Company Dba At&t Michigan
CaseSummary: Incumbent telephone service provider was required under 47 U.S.C.S. § 251(c)(2) to provide competitors with cost-based access to existing entrance facilities for interconnection; the FCC's determination that cost-based unbundled access to entrance facilities was not required under § 251(c)(3) did not alter the § 251(c)(2) obligation.

CaseName: Janus Capital Group, Inc., Et Al., Petitioners V. First Derivative Traders
CaseSummary: There was no allegation that an investment advisor filed prospectuses and falsely attributed them to a mutual fund, nor did the prospectuses indicate that they came from the advisor instead of the fund; thus, the advisor did not "make" allegedly misleading statements, and claims under 17 C.F.R. § 240.10b-5(b) and 15 U.S.C.S. § 78j(b) failed.

CaseName: Nevada Commission On Ethics, Petitioner V. Michael A. Carrigan
CaseSummary: Nevada's Ethics in Government Law's recusal provision was not unconstitutionally overbroad under the First Amendment because legislators lacked a personal First Amendment right to vote on any given matter since, inter alia, belief that recusal rules violated legislators' First Amendment rights was inconsistent with early congressional enactments.

CaseName: Borough Of Duryea, Pennsylvania, Et Al., Petitioners V. Charles J Guarnieri
CaseSummary: Where a public employee alleged retaliation under the Petition Clause of the First Amendment and was awarded compensatory damages, remand was warranted because the public concern test limited Petition Clause claims by public employees, and the employee had to show that his union grievance and lawsuit related to a matter of public concern.

CaseName: American Electric Power Company, Inc., Et Al., Petitioners V. Connecticut Et Al
CaseSummary: The Clean Air Act and the EPA actions it authorized under 42 U.S.C.S. § 7411 displaced any federal common law right, through States' federal common law public nuisance claims, to seek the setting of carbon-dioxide emissions for power plants by the federal courts; the Second Circuit's finding that the claims were not displaced was reversed.

CaseName: Csx Transportation, Inc., Petitioner V. Robert Mcbride
CaseSummary: In a negligence action under FELA, 45 U.S.C.S. § 51 et seq., district court properly refused to give a jury a common-law tort law proximate cause instruction because a proper charge in FELA cases informed juries that a railroad caused or contributed to an employee's injury if the railroad's negligence played any part in bringing about the injury.

CaseName: Sorrell, Attorney General Of Vermont, Et Al. V. Ims Health Inc. Et Al
CaseSummary: Vt. Stat. Ann. tit. 18, § 4631(d), violated the First Amendment as incorporated by the Fourteenth Amendment, because while Vermont's stated policy goals of lowering the costs of medical services and promoting public health may have been proper, § 4631(d) did not advance them in a permissible way. It was a broad, content-based rule.

CaseName: Edmund G. Brown, Jr., Governor Of California, Et Al., Petitioners V. Entertainment Merchants Association, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1746-1746.5, which prohibited the sale or rental of "violent video games" to minors, violated the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution because it was both underinclusive and overinclusive. The statute did not preclude minors from having access to information about violence in other forms, only in video games.

CaseName: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club Pac, Et Al., Petitioners V. Ken Bennett, In His Official Capacity As Arizona Secretary Of State, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Leveling the playing field was not a compelling interest justifying undue burdens on First Amendment speech by Ariz. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 16-952(A), (B), (C)(4)-(5), which matched, with public funds paid to a publicly financed candidate, each dollar spent by a privately funded candidate (PrFC) or independent expenditure group supporting a PrFC.

CaseName: Compucredit Corporation Et Al. V. Wanda Greenwood Et Al.
CaseSummary: District court erred when it found that arbitration agreements consumers signed when they obtained a credit card were unenforceable under the Credit Repair Organizations Act, 15 U.S.C.S. § 1679 et seq. The Federal Arbitration Act required that the arbitration agreements the consumers signed be enforced according to their terms.

CaseName: Pacific Operators Offshore, Llp, Et Al. V. Luisa L. Valladolid Et Al
CaseSummary: U.S. Supreme Court adopted the "substantial nexus" test which the Ninth Circuit used to determine if a widow was entitled to compensation under the LHWCA and 43 U.S.C.S. § 1333(b). The widow had to establish that there was a "substantial nexus" between her husband's death onshore and the employer's extractive operations on outer Continental Shelf.

CaseName: Hosanna-tabor Evangelical Lutheran Church And School V. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Et Al.
CaseSummary: The ministerial exception, grounded in the First Amendment, precluded application of 42 U.S.C.S. § 12203(a), the retaliation prohibition of the ADA, to a church's firing of a narcoleptic teacher who held the title of minister. Both Religion Clauses barred the government from interfering with the decision of a religious group to fire a minister.

CaseName: Marcus D. Mims, Petitioner V. Arrow Financial Services, Llc
CaseSummary: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C.S. § 227(b)(3), did not require a private suit to be brought in state court; federal and state courts had concurrent jurisdiction. A private TCPA claim arose under the laws of the United States, and § 227(b)(3) did not divest federal courts of their 28 U.S.C.S. § 1331 federal-question jurisdiction.

CaseName: Lawrence Golan, Et Al. V. Eric H. Holder, Jr., Attorney General, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Section 514 of Uruguay Round Agreements Act, which granted copyright protection to foreign works previously in public domain, did not violate U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 8, or First Amendment, since works were not required to remain in public domain, copyright limits protected free speech, and there were no vested rights in works in public domain.

CaseName: Ppl Montana, Llc, Petitioner V. Montana
CaseSummary: Montana Supreme Court erred when it found that Montana owned riverbeds where a power company's facilities were located because the rivers in question were navigable at those locations. The court should have considered the rivers in question on a segment-by-segment basis to determine ownership of the riverbeds, and it failed to do so.

CaseName: Dana Roberts, Petitioner V. Sea-land Services, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: ALJ did not err when he awarded an employee, who filed a claim after his employer terminated the disability benefits that he was receiving under the LHWCA, at the maximum rate authorized for 2002, the year when the employee was injured, and not at the maximum rate authorized for 2007, the year when the ALJ issued his decision.

CaseName: Mayo Collaborative Services, Dba Mayo Medical Laboratories, Et Al., Petitioners V. Prometheus Laboratories, Inc.
CaseSummary: Patents describing use of thiopurine drugs to treat autoimmune diseases contained unpatentable subject matter since correlation between blood metabolite levels and drugs were known laws of nature, and steps of administering drugs, applying natural laws in treatment, and measuring metabolite levels lacked inventive concept in applying natural laws.

CaseName: Credit Suisse Securities (Usa) Llc, Et Al., Petitioners V. Vanessa Simmonds
CaseSummary: Shareholder's action alleging that underwriters of initial public offerings were required to disgorge profits from short-swing insider trading were time-barred by two-year limitations period of 15 U.S.C.S. § 78p(b), since period expressly began to run when profits were realized rather than when underwriters filed statements disclosing profits.

CaseName: Chantell Sackett, Et Vir, Petitioners V. Environmental Protection Agency, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Property owners had the right to judicial review of their claims that the EPA acted arbitrarily and capriciously and deprived them of due process of law when it issued a compliance order under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1319 which accused them of discharging pollutants into a navigable waterway without a permit, in violation of 33 U.S.C.S. § 1311.

CaseName: Caraco Pharmaceutical Laboratories, Ltd., Et Al., Petitioners V. Novo Nordisk A/s Et Al.
CaseSummary: Drug manufacturers' competitor was entitled to seek correction of manufacturers' use code for its method-of-use patent under 21 U.S.C.S. § 355 to permit approval of competitor's proposed generic drug which claimed other uses, since manufacturers' claim of one use did not preclude challenge and use code was patent information subject to correction.

CaseName: Asid Mohamad, Individually And For The Estate Of Azzam Rahim, Deceased, Et Al., Petitioners V. Palestinian Authority Et Al.
CaseSummary: Relatives of a naturalized citizen who was an alleged victim of torture could not sue Palestinian organizations under the Torture Victim Protection Act (TVPA), 28 U.S.C.S. § 1350 note, because the TVPA did not impose liability against organizations; the term "individual" as used in the TVPA encompassed only natural persons.

CaseName: David J. Kappos, Under Secretary Of Commerce For Intellectual Property And Director, Patent And Trademark Office, Petitioner V. Gilbert P. Hyatt
CaseSummary: 35 U.S.C.S. § 145 neither imposed unique evidentiary limits in district court proceedings nor established a heightened standard of review for the PTO's factual findings, thus, vacating a summary judgment granted to the PTO on the basis of excluding a patent applicant's new evidence that had not been before the PTO was proper.

CaseName: Tammy Foret Freeman, Et Al., Petitioners V. Quicken Loans, Inc.
CaseSummary: Mortgage lenders were entitled to summary judgment on claims brought under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act because 12 U.S.C.S. § 2607(b) unambiguously covered only a settlement-service provider's splitting of a fee with one or more other persons; it could not be understood to reach a single provider's retention of an unearned fee.

CaseName: Christine Armour, Et Al., Petitioners V. City Of Indianapolis, Indiana, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Change in city's sewer-project funding method which forgave future installment assessments but provided no refunds for prepaid assessments did not violate Equal Protection Clause, U.S. Const. amend. XIV, cl. 1, since city had rational basis for distinction based on administrative burdens of continuing to collect installments or processing refunds.

CaseName: United States, Petitioner V. Xavier Alvarez
CaseSummary: Supreme Court upheld the court of appeals' decision reversing a district court's judgment convicting respondent of violating the Stolen Valor Act, 18 U.S.C.S. § 704(b), by falsely claiming that he was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor because the Act violated the First Amendment.

CaseName: Already, Llc, Dba Yums, Petitioner V. Nike, Inc.
CaseSummary: In a trademark infringement action filed by a shoe company, it was not error to find that a subsequently-filed covenant not to sue mooted the case and divested the district court of jurisdiction; therefore, the district court also could not hear a counterclaim alleging the shoe company’s trademark was invalid.

CaseName: Los Angeles County Flood Control District Petitioner V. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: The flow of water from an improved, concrete channel portion of a navigable waterway into an unimproved portion of the very same waterway did not qualify as a discharge of pollutants under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1362(12) of the Clean Water Act; thus, a finding of liability against a water district was in error.

CaseName: Federal Trade Commission, Petitioner V. Phoebe Putney Health System, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: State legislation granting hospital authority power to acquire hospitals did not implicate state-action immunity from antitrust violations in acquiring only hospitals in authority's jurisdiction, since legislation did not clearly articulate policy of allowing anticompetitive acquisitions nor was any such policy implied as reasonably foreseeable.

CaseName: Olivea Marx, Petitioner V. General Revenue Corporation
CaseSummary: 15 U.S.C.S. § 1692k(a)(3) did not “provide otherwise” for purposes of Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(d)(1), thus the district court was not precluded from awarding costs to a prevailing FDCPA debt collector defendant in a borrower's FDCPA case without finding bad faith and harassment.

CaseName: Marc J. Gabelli And Bruce Alpert, Petitioners V. Securities And Exchange Commission
CaseSummary: SEC enforcement action seeking civil penalties under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, 15 U.S.C.S. § 80b-9, was time-barred under 28 U.S.C.S. § 2462 because the action was filed more than five years after the allegedly violative conduct occurred, and the discovery rule was inapplicable to this government enforcement action for civil penalties.

CaseName: Amgen Inc., Et Al., Petitioners V. Connecticut Retirement Plans And Trust Funds
CaseSummary: Proof of materiality of misrepresentations was not a prerequisite under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b) to certification of a class of investors in a securities-fraud class action, since materiality could be proved through evidence common to the class, and a failure of proof of materiality thus would end the action rather than simply prevent certification.

CaseName: Steven Alan Levin, Petitioner V. United States Et Al.
CaseSummary: The Gonzalez Act's direction in 10 U.S.C.S. § 1089(e) abrogated the FTCA's intentional tort exception, 28 U.S.C.S. § 2680(h), and permitted a veteran's lawsuit against the United States alleging that a Navy doctor committed battery while acting within the scope of his employment, when he performed surgery after the veteran withdrew his consent.

CaseName: Supap Kirtsaeng, Dba Bluechristine99, Petitioner V. John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
CaseSummary: 17 U.S.C.S. § 109(a)’s first sale doctrine applied to copies of American copyrighted books manufactured abroad, thus, a student could assert the defense where he had others buy the books in Thailand, send them to him, and he resold them at a profit.

CaseName: Doug Decker, In His Official Capacity As Oregon State Forester, Et Al., Petitioners V. Northwest Environmental Defense Center;
CaseSummary: Preamendment version of the Industrial Stormwater Rule, former 40 C.F.R. § 122.26(b)(14) (2006), was reasonably interpreted by the EPA to exempt discharges of channeled stormwater runoff from logging roads from the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit requirement under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1342(p).

CaseName: Kim Millbrook, Petitioner V. United States
CaseSummary: 28 U.S.C.S. § 2680(h)'s “law enforcement proviso” did not apply only to torts during executing searches, seizures, or arrests, or when officers were engaged in investigative or law enforcement activity, thus, immunity did not apply to a prisoner's claim against the U.S. for federal correction officers' assault and battery.

CaseName: Us Airways, Inc., In Its Capacity As Fiduciary And Plan Administrator Of The Us Airways, Inc. Employee Benefits Plan, Petitioner V. James E. Mccutchen Et Al.
CaseSummary: Employer was allowed under 29 U.S.C.S. § 1132(a)(3) to enforce a health benefits plan description which required an injured employee to reimburse medical payments the plan paid from amounts he received from a tortfeasor and his own insurer. However, remand was required so lower courts could determine amount of attorneys' fees employer had to pay.

CaseName: Randy Curtis Bullock, Petitioner V. Bankchampaign, N. A.
CaseSummary: Nonprofessional trustee was improperly denied a discharge of a debt in bankruptcy based on fiduciary defalcation under 11 U.S.C.S. § 523(a)(4) since the trustee repaid loans for the trustee's personal gain from a trust with interest and there was no finding of wrongful intent, or gross recklessness, as required to find defalcation.

CaseName: Vernon Hugh Bowman, Petitioner V. Monsanto Company Et Al.
CaseSummary: The patent exhaustion doctrine did not protect a farmer who reproduced patented seeds through planting and harvesting without the patent holder’s permission because the farmer planted the holder’s patented soybeans solely to make and market replicas of them, thus depriving the holder of the reward patent law provided for the sale of each article.

CaseName: Oxford Health Plans Llc, Petitioner V. John Ivan Sutter
CaseSummary: Where insurer sought to vacate arbitrator's decision that a contract authorized class arbitration, arbitrator's decision survived the limited judicial review FAA § 10(a)(4) allowed because question was not whether he construed the contract correctly, but whether he construed it at all, and his decisions were interpretations of the agreement.

CaseName: Agency For International Development, Et Al., Petitioners V. Alliance For Open Society International, Inc., Et Al.
CaseSummary: Requirement that organizations receiving funding under the U.S. Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Act to fight the spread of HIV/AIDS adopt a policy explicitly opposing prostitution violated the organizations' freedom of speech, since the requirement compelled speech outside the scope of the funding program.

CaseName: American Express Company, Et Al., Petitioners V. Italian Colors Restaurant, Et Al.
CaseSummary: Provision in an arbitration agreement merchants entered with a credit card company which provided that they did not have the right to arbitrate any claim "on a class action basis" was not invalid because costs they would incur to individually arbitrate their claim alleging that company violated the Sherman Act would far exceed potential recovery.

CaseName: Hollingsworth V. Perry
CaseSummary: Proponents of Proposition 8, which was enacted as Cal. Const. art. I, § 7.5 and provided that marriage was solely between a man and a woman, lacked standing under U.S. Const. art. III, § 2 to appeal a district court decision that declared Proposition 8 unconstitutional. The proponents' interest in the initiative's validity was insufficient.

CaseName: United States V. Windsor
CaseSummary: Defense of Marriage Act, which denied recognition of same-sex marriages, was unconstitutional since the disallowance of a surviving-spouse estate tax exemption based on the same-sex marriage of the spouse and the decedent, which was recognized by the state, was a deprivation of the equal liberty of persons that was protected by the Fifth Amendment.

CaseName: Heimeshoff V. Hartford Life & Accident Ins. Co.
CaseSummary: A limitations provision was enforceable where a participant and a plan were allowed to agree by contract to a particular limitations period, even one that started to run before the cause of action accrued, the three-year limitations period was not unreasonably short, and ERISA was not a controlling statute to the contrary.

CaseName: Medtronic, Inc. V. Mirowski Family Ventures, Llc
CaseSummary: Although a patentee was a defendant in an action which a medical products company filed under the Declaratory Judgment Act seeking a judgment that it was not required to pay royalties to the patentee under a license it held, the patentee had the burden of proving that products the company produced infringed its patents.

CaseName: Air Wisconsin Airlines Corp. V. Hoeper
CaseSummary: Where an airline called TSA about a pilot's anger, chance that he might be armed, and impending termination, the airline was entitled to immunity under the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) regarding a defamation claim because, inter alia, ATSA immunity could not be denied without determination that disclosure was materially false.

CaseName: Chadbourne & Parke Llp V. Troice
CaseSummary: Investors' consolidated class actions under the Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C.S. §§ 78bb(f ), were erroneously dismissed because a fraudulent misrepresentation or omission was not made in connection with a purchase or sale of a covered security unless it was material to a decision to buy or sell a covered security.

CaseName: Law V. Siegel
CaseSummary: Bankruptcy debtor's homestead exemption was improperly surcharged to defray a bankruptcy trustee's attorney fees in establishing that the debtor claimed a fraudulent lien against the debtor's homestead, since the surcharge contravened 11 U.S.C.S. § 522(k), which provided that the exemption was not liable for payment of administrative expenses.

CaseName: Bg Group Plc V. Republic Of Argentina
CaseSummary: Arbitrators had authority to determine that treaty provision requiring local litigation prior to arbitration did not apply since treaty was contract and subject to contractual presumption that parties to treaty intended arbitrators rather than courts to decide dispute about interpretation and application of procedural precondition for arbitration.

CaseName: Mccutcheon V. Fec
CaseSummary: Aggregate limits that were imposed under 2 U.S.C.S. § 441a(a)(3) on amounts individuals could contribute to candidates and political committees violated First Amendment because they restricted right to participate in the political process while doing little, if anything, to target “quid pro quo” corruption or its appearance in campaign financing.

CaseName: Paroline V. United States
CaseSummary: 18 U.S.C.S. § 2259 limited restitution to those losses proximately caused by defendant's possession of child pornography; the lower court erred in finding otherwise. On remand, the district court was to assess the significance of defendant’s conduct in light of the broader causal process that produced the victim’s losses.

CaseName: Epa V. Eme Homer City Generation
CaseSummary: The EPA's Transport Rule, 76 Fed. Reg. 48208-48209, which provided a cost-effective allocation of emission reductions among upwind states, was not arbitrary and capricious, but was a permissible, workable, and equitable interpretation of the "Good Neighbor Provision" of the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C.S. § 7410(a).

CaseName: Town Of Greece V. Galloway
CaseSummary: Town's practice of opening board meetings with a prayer did not violate the Establishment Clause; the First Amendment did not require legislative prayer to be nonsectarian, nor was the town required to search beyond its borders for non-Christian prayer givers in order to achieve religious balancing.

CaseName: Petrella V. Metro-goldwyn-mayer, Inc.
CaseSummary: The equitable defense of laches did not bar relief on a screenplay writer's heir's pursuit of 17 U.S.C.S. § 504(b) remedies that had been brought within 17 U.S.C.S. § 507(b)’s three-year limitations period as § 507(b) already took account of delay by limiting recovery for infringement in earlier years allowing offsets for deductible expenses.

CaseName: Wood V. Moss
CaseSummary: In action alleging First Amendment violation due to how security perimeter was established, Secret Service agents were entitled to qualified immunity as no decision would have alerted agents engaged in crowd control that they bore First Amendment obligation to ensure that groups with different viewpoints were at comparable locations at all times.

CaseName: Limelight Networks, Inc. V. Akamai Technologies, Inc.
CaseSummary: Under statutory text and structure, as well as prior case law, a content delivery network provider could not be liable for inducing infringement of a patent under 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(b) when no one had directly infringed the patent under 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(a) or any other statutory provision.

CaseName: Nautilus, Inc. V. Biosig Instruments, Inc
CaseSummary: An incorrect standard was applied in finding that a patent for a heart-rate monitor was not indefinite under 35 U.S.C.S. § 112, para. 2, because a patent would be indefinite if its claims, in light of the specification and prosecution history, failed to inform, with reasonable certainty, those skilled in the art about the scope of the invention.

CaseName: Executive Benefits Ins. Agency V. Arkison
CaseSummary: In a bankruptcy case, the plain text of the severability provision of 28 U.S.C.S. § 157(c) closed the so-called "gap" created by a Stern claim, and thus, the proper course in such a case required a bankruptcy court to issue proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law for de novo review and entry of a judgment by a district court.

CaseName: Pom Wonderful Llc V. Coca-cola Co.
CaseSummary: Producer of a blended juice beverage was not precluded by the FDCA from an action under the Lanham Act alleging that a competitor mislabeled its beverage, since regulating labeling for consumer protection under the FDCA was complementary to the prohibition of mislabeling under the Lanham Act for the protection of competition.

CaseName: Halliburton Co. V. Erica P. John Fund, Inc.
CaseSummary: Although the presumption of reliance upon a corporation's misrepresentations in securities fraud action based on stock price in efficient market remained viable, corporation was entitled to present evidence of lack of market efficiency with evidence of lack of impact of misrepresentations on price to rebut presumption prior to class certification.

CaseName: Util. Air Regulatory Group V. Epa
CaseSummary: EPA impermissibly determined that stationary sources could be required to obtain a Clean Air Act permit on the basis of greenhouse-gas emissions, but EPA reasonably determined that the Act required best available control technology for greenhouse gases emitted by sources that were otherwise subject to Prevention of Significant Deterioration review.

CaseName: Fifth Third Bancorp V. Dudenhoeffer
CaseSummary: Under 29 U.S.C.S. § 1104(a)(1)(B), ESOP fiduciaries were subject to the same duty of prudence that applied to ERISA fiduciaries in general, except that they were not required to diversify the fund’s assets. The fiduciaries' arguments to the contrary were rejected.

CaseName: American Broadcasting Cos. V. Aereo, Inc.
CaseSummary: Business that sold service which allowed subscribers to watch television programs over Internet at about same time programs were broadcast violated copyrights held by television producers and broadcasters, and could be enjoined from providing that service; the service was a "public" performance under changes Congress made to Copyright Act in 1976.

CaseName: Mccullen V. Coakley
CaseSummary: Mass. Gen. Laws, ch. 266, § 120E1/2(a), (b) (2012) violated the First Amendment where although it was content neutral, the buffer zones compromised the abortion opponents' abilities to engage in sidewalk counseling and distribute literature to arriving patients, and the Commonwealth had other approaches that did not exclude them from public ways.

CaseName: Burwell V. Hobby Lobby Stores
CaseSummary: Regulations requiring that closely held corporations, whose owners had sincere religious beliefs regarding contraception, provide health insurance coverage for contraception violated the RFRA because the regulations substantially burdened the exercise of religion and were not the least restrictive means of serving a compelling government interest.

CaseName: Lane V. Franks
CaseSummary: Testimony that a public employee gave in two prosecutions the U.S. Government initiated against a state legislator who worked for a community college, which alleged that the legislator committed mail fraud and theft, was protected by the First Amendment because it was speech by a citizen on a matter of public concern.

CaseName: Alice Corp. Pty. Ltd. V. Cls Bank Int'l
CaseSummary: Patent claims disclosing a computer-implemented scheme for mitigating settlement risk by using a third-party intermediary were patent-ineligible under 35 U.S.C.S. § 101 as they were drawn to a patent-ineligible abstract idea. Merely requiring generic computer implementation failed to transform that abstract idea into a patent-eligible invention.

CaseName: Holt V. Hobbs
CaseSummary: State prison's policy preventing inmate from growing short beard violated RLUIPA since it was undisputed that policy substantially burdened inmate's sincerely held religious belief that beard was required by his religion, and policy was not least restrictive means of furthering prison interests in preventing contraband and identifying inmates.

CaseName: Nc Bd. Of Dental Examiners V. Ftc
CaseSummary: A state board on which a controlling number of decisionmakers were active market participants in the occupation the board regulated had to satisfy the Midcal active supervision requirement in order to invoke state-action antitrust immunity.

CaseName: Teva Pharms. Usa, Inc. V. Sandoz, Inc.
Omnicare, Inc. V. Laborers Dist. Council Constr. Indus. Pension Fund
CaseSummary: Issuer's statements that it believed its contracts were legal did not give rise to liability under the first clause of 15 U.S.C.S. § 77k(a); investors did not allege that the opinion was not honestly held, and the statements therefore were not "untrue statements of material fact" regardless of whether the belief could be proved wrong.

CaseName: Dep't Of Homeland Sec. V. Maclean
CaseSummary: TSA violated 5 U.S.C.S. § 2302(b)(8)(A) when it fired air marshal because he told reporter that TSA had decided to remove air marshals from certain long-distance flights to save money on hotel costs, even though it had credible information that al Qaeda was planning to attack flights, because disclosure was prohibited by regulation, not by statute.

CaseName: Jesinoski V. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc.
CaseSummary: The borrowers' complaint was improperly dismissed as untimely where they had mailed the lenders a written notice of their intention to rescind within three years of their mortgage loan's consummation, and that was all that was required in order to exercise the right to rescind under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1635(a).

CaseName: M&g Polymers Usa, Llc V. Tackett
CaseSummary: A collective bargaining agreement was not shown to vest retirees with right to lifetime contribution-free health benefits since there was no presumption of vested benefits, there was no evidence that industry customarily vested benefits, limited term of agreement could not be disregarded, and silence did not infer that benefits vested for life.

CaseName: Ala. Dep't Of Revenue V. Csx Transp., Inc.
CaseSummary: Alabama could be found not to have discriminated against a rail carrier in violation of 49 U.S.C.S. § 11501(b)(4) by exempting motor carriers, but not rail carriers, from a sales and use tax on diesel fuel if a fuel-excise tax imposed on motor carriers, but not rail carriers, was determined to be the rough equivalent of the sales tax.

CaseName: Comptroller Of The Treasury V. Wynne
CaseSummary: Maryland statutes that imposed a tax on income Maryland residents earned outside Maryland violated the Dormant Commerce Clause under the internal consistency test as they did not offer Maryland residents full credit against income taxes paid to other States and created an incentive for Maryland taxpayers to opt for intrastate economic activity.

CaseName: B&b Hardware, Inc. V. Hargis Indus., Inc.
CaseSummary: So long as the other ordinary elements of issue preclusion were met, when the usages adjudicated by the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board were materially the same as those before the district court, issue preclusion should be applied.

CaseName: Young V. Ups
CaseSummary: The lower courts improperly granted an employer summary judgment on a pregnant employee's 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000e(k) claim where the employee's evidence created a genuine dispute as to whether the employer provided more favorable treatment to at least some employees whose situation could not be distinguished.

CaseName: Hana Financial, Inc. V. Hana Bank
CaseSummary: Issue of whether tacking was available to determine trademark priority was properly submitted to the jury. Because the tacking inquiry operated from the perspective of an ordinary purchaser, if a jury trial was requested the jury was required to make the determination unless the facts warranted summary judgment or judgment as a matter of law.

CaseName: Direct Mktg. Ass'n V. Brohl
CaseSummary: 28 U.S.C.S. § 1341 did not bar a suit to enjoin enforcement of Colo. Rev. Stat. § 39-21-112 where enforcement of the notice and reporting requirements was not an act of assessment, levy, or collection, and a suit could not be understood to restrain the assessment, levy, or collection of a state tax if it merely inhibited those activities.

CaseName: Dot V. Ass'n Of Am. R.r.
CaseSummary: The National Railroad Passenger Corporation (Amtrak) was a governmental entity, not a private one, for purposes of determining whether the adoption of metrics and standards violated the United States Constitution's structural separation of powers and the Appointments Clause, U.S. Const. art. II, § 2, cl. 2.

CaseName: United States V. Kwai Fun Wong
CaseSummary: 28 U.S.C.S. § 2401(b)(1) was nonjurisdictional and subject to equitable tolling as neither the text, context, nor legislative history indicated that Congress meant to enact something other than a standard time bar, and case law created a rebuttable presumption of equitable tolling against the government under a statute waiving sovereign immunity.

CaseName: Kellogg Brown & Root Services, Inc. V. United States Ex Rel. Carter
CaseSummary: Civil fraud claims of a former employee of defense contractors in a qui tam action on behalf of the government against the contractors were precluded since the Wartime Suspension of Limitations Act applied to any offense involving fraud or attempted fraud against the government, and the term "offense" limited application of the statute to crimes.

CaseName: Reed V. Town Of Gilbert
CaseSummary: Provisions in a town's sign code, Gilbert, Ariz., Land Development Code, ch. 1, § 4.402 (2005), which imposed more stringent restrictions on signs directing the public to a meeting of a nonprofit group than it did on signs conveying other messages, were content-based regulations of speech that could not survive First Amendment strict scrutiny.

CaseName: Tibble V. Edison International
CaseSummary: Appellate court erred by applying 6-year statutory bar based solely on initial selection of mutual funds without considering contours of alleged breach of fiduciary duty because, so long as alleged breach of continuing duty to monitor investments and remove imprudent ones occurred within six years of suit, claim was timely under 29 U.S.C.S. § 1113.

CaseName: Williams Yulee V. The Florida Bar
CaseSummary: Fla. Code Jud. Conduct Canon 7C(1), which prohibited candidates in judicial elections from personally soliciting campaign funds, did not violate the First Amendment; the Canon was narrowly tailored to serve the state's compelling interest in protecting the integrity of the judiciary and maintaining public confidence in an impartial judiciary.

CaseName: Tmobile South, Llc V.city Of Roswell, Georgia.
CaseSummary: Telecommunications Act of 1996, 47 U.S.C.S. § 332(c)(7)(B)(iii), required localities to provide reasons when they denied a cell phone tower siting application; the reasons did not have to appear in the written denial itself, but could instead appear in some other written record issued essentially contemporaneously with the denial.

CaseName: Walker V. Texas Division, Sons Of Confederate Veterans, Inc.
CaseSummary: Where the Texas Department of Motor Vehicles Board rejected a proposed specialty license plate design featuring a Confederate battle flag, the rejection did not violate the First Amendment's free speech guarantees because specialty license plates issued pursuant to Texas’s statutory scheme conveyed government speech.

CaseName: Bank Of America, N.a. V. Caulkett
CaseSummary: The reasoning of judicial precedent dictated that a debtor in a Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceeding could not void a junior mortgage lien under 11 U.S.C.S. § 506(d) when the debt owed on a senior mortgage lien exceeded the current value of the collateral.

CaseName: Michigan V. Environmental Protection Agency
CaseSummary: EPA interpreted the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C.S. § 7412(n)(1)(A), unreasonably when it deemed cost irrelevant to the decision to regulate power plants because the statutory directive of determining whether power plant regulation was "appropriate and necessary" required attention to cost, which included more than expense of complying with regulations.

CaseName: Commil Usa, Llc V. Cisco Systems, Inc.
CaseSummary: Defendant's belief regarding patent validity was not a defense to a claim under 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(b) of induced infringement; invalidity was a defense to liability, not to infringement, and a belief as to invalidity therefore could not negate the scienter required for induced infringement.

CaseName: Kimble V. Marvel Enterprises, Inc.
CaseSummary: Overruling precedent that patentee could not continue to receive royalties after patent expired was not warranted since stare decisis favored settled law, precedent did not preclude arrangements other than royalties, policy favored unrestricted use of expired patents, overruling would affect other precedents, and precedent was simple and workable.

CaseName: Harris V. Viegelahn
CaseSummary: Where Chapter 13 debtor converted to Chapter 7, he was entitled to return of any postpetition wages not yet distributed by Chapter 13 trustee because, by excluding postpetition wages from converted Chapter 7 estate, 11 U.S.C.S. § 348(f)(1)(A) removed those earnings from pool of assets that might have been liquidated and distributed to creditors.

CaseName: Obergefell V. Hodges
CaseSummary: Under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, same-sex couples have a fundamental right to marry, and state laws excluding same-sex couples from civil marriage were held invalid; states cannot refuse to recognize a lawful same-sex marriage performed in another state on the ground of its same-sex character.

CaseName: Obb Personenverkehr Ag V. Sachs
CaseSummary: A rail passenger failed to show that her action against a foreign railway operator fell within 28 U.S.C.S. § 1605(a)(2)'s commercial activity exception where she sought to recover for injuries suffered when she fell when attempting to board a train in Austria, and her claims were not based upon her purchase of a Eurail pass in the United States.

CaseName: Directv, Inc. V. Imburgia
CaseSummary: California court's determination that a class arbitration waiver was unenforceable was preempted by the Federal Arbitration Act; California's anti-waiver rule was invalid, and a finding that the arbitration provision incorporated invalid state law would not place the arbitration provision on equal footing with other contracts.

CaseName: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission V. Electric Power Supply Association
CaseSummary: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission had authority to require wholesale electric market operators to pay same price to demand response providers for conserving energy as to generators for producing it so long as consumers actually saved money, since rule directly affected wholesale rate which was reduced by displacing higher-priced generation bids.

CaseName: Lockhart V. United States
CaseSummary: Defendant's sentence for possession of child pornography was properly enhanced under 18 U.S.C.S. § 2252(b)(2) based on prior state conviction for sexual abuse of adult, since phrase “involving minor or ward” modified only abusive sexual conduct under rule of last antecedent and did not modify convictions for aggravated sexual abuse or sexual abuse.

CaseName: Montanile V. Bd. Of National Elevator Industry Health Benefit Plan
CaseSummary: When a participant dissipated the whole settlement on nontraceable items, the fiduciary could not bring a suit to attach the participant’s general assets under § 502(a)(3) of ERISA, 29 U.S.C.S. § 1132(a)(3), because the suit was not one for appropriate equitable relief.

CaseName: Kingdomware Technologies, Inc., V. United States
CaseSummary: VA improperly awarded contracts without restricted competition to veteran-owned small businesses since rule requiring determination whether there was reasonable expectation that two or more veteran-owned small businesses would bid for contract was mandatory and applied to all contracts awarded by VA regardless of method of procurement.

CaseName: California Franchise Tax Board V. Hyatt
CaseSummary: Nevada's decision to apply a special rule of law allowing damages awards greater than $50,000 violated U.S. Const. art. IV, § 1, where the rule applied only in lawsuits against sister States, and as a result, the decision reflected a constitutionally impermissible policy of hostility to the public acts of a sister State.

CaseName: Bank Markazi V. Peterson
CaseSummary: 22 U.S.C.S. § 8772, which made available for postjudgment execution set of assets held at New York bank for Central Bank of Iran to partially satisfy judgments obtained by over 1,000 victims of terrorist acts sponsored by Iran, did not offend separation of powers principles protecting role of an independent Judiciary within constitutional design.

CaseName: Heffernan V. City Of Paterson, New Jersey
CaseSummary: City police officer who was observed carrying campaign sign for delivery to parent was entitled to seek relief for officer's demotion based on city's mistaken belief that officer was engaging in political speech, since city acted upon constitutionally harmful policy regardless of whether officer did or did not in fact engage in political activity.

CaseName: Sturgeon V. Frost
CaseSummary: Interpretation of 16 U.S.C.S. § 3103(c) was rejected as Act contemplated possibility that all land within boundaries of conservation system units in Alaska may have been treated differently from federally managed preservation areas across country, and that non-public lands within unit may have been treated differently from public lands within unit.

CaseName: Halo Electronics V. Pulse Electronics
CaseSummary: U.S. Court of Appeals for Federal Circuit's decisions affirming district court judgments in separate patent infringement actions where issue of increased damages under 35 U.S.C.S. § 284 was addressed were vacated because Federal Circuit used test it adopted in In re Seagate Technology to review both cases and that test was inconsistent with § 284.

CaseName: Husky International Electronics, Inc., V. Ritz
CaseSummary: Prohibition of a bankruptcy discharge for "actual fraud" under 11 U.S.C.S. § 523(a)(2)(A) encompasses fraudulent conveyance schemes, even when those schemes do not involve a false representation.

CaseName: Whole Woman's Health V. Hellerstedt
CaseSummary: Tex. Health & Safety Code Ann. § 171.0031(a), which imposed admitting-privileges requirements on abortion providers, and Tex. Health & Safety Code Ann. § 245.010(a), which required abortion facilities to meet surgical center requirements, were unconstitutional; medical benefits did not justify the undue burden on abortion access.

CaseName: Rjr Nabisco Inc. V. European Community
CaseSummary: RICO, 18 U.S.C.S. § 1962, applies to foreign racketeering activity as long as the predicate offense involves a statute that is extraterritorial; however, the private right of action under 18 U.S.C.S. § 1964(c) requires a domestic injury to business or property, and domestic injury claims against a cigarette company in the instant case were waived.

CaseName: Simmons V. Himmelreich
CaseSummary: The language “the provisions of this chapter shall not apply” set forth in 28 U.S.C.S. § 2680(a) was to be read as it was written, and as a result, the judgment bar provision, 28 U.S.C.S. § 2676, which was one of the “provisions of this chapter,” did not apply to the categories of claims in the exceptions sections of the Federal Tort Claims Act.

CaseName: United States Army Corp Of Engineers V. Hawkes Co., Inc.
CaseSummary: Approved jurisdictional determination U.S. Army Corps of Engineers issued after three companies applied for permit under 33 U.S.C.S. § 1344(a) to remove peat from property they owned, which found that property contained "waters of the United States," was final agency action that was reviewable in federal district court pursuant to 5 U.S.C.S. § 704.

CaseName: Puerto Rico V. Franklin California Tax Free Trust
CaseSummary: Puerto Rico was not a state for purposes of 11 U.S.C.S. § 109(c) and could not perform the single function of the states under that provision, but because it remained a state for purposes of 11 U.S.C.S. § 903(1), it was barred from enacting its own municipal bankruptcy scheme to restructure the debt of its insolvent public utilities companies.

CaseName: Zubik V. Burwell
CaseSummary: Where providers of health insurance to employees challenged regulations requiring them to cover certain contraceptives, unless they submitted a specific notice of objection, parties on remand were afforded opportunity to arrive at approach that accommodated providers' religious exercise while ensuring that women received contraceptive coverage.

CaseName: Universal Health Services, Inc. V. Escobar, Julio, Et Al
CaseSummary: Implied false certification theory can be a basis for liability under the False Claims Act, 31 U.S.C.S. § 3729(a)(1)(A), at least where specific representations are made about the goods or services provided, and a failure to disclose noncompliance with material statutory, regulatory, or contractual requirements makes the representations misleading.

CaseName: Cuozzo Speed Technologies, Llc V. Lee
CaseSummary: Court of appeals did not err when it found that LLC that held U.S. Patent No. 6,778,074, which described speedometer that showed driver when he was speeding, did not have right under 35 U.S.C.S. § 314(d) to appeal PTO's decision to initiate inter partes review because, inter alia, competitor's challenge did not implicate a constitutional question.

CaseName: Samsung Electronics V. Apple
CaseSummary: The term "article of manufacture," as used in 35 U.S.C.S. § 289, encompassed both a product sold to a consumer and a component of that product, and thus, the lower court's basis for not limiting the award, i.e., that the component parts of a manufacturer's smartphones were not sold separately from their shells, was in error.

CaseName: Star Athletica, L.l.c. V. Varsity Brands, Inc.
CaseSummary: The United States Court of Appeals for Sixth Circuit did not err when it found that graphics that were used by a company that manufactured cheerleading uniforms were copyrightable under 17 U.S.C.S. § 101 because they could be identified separately and were capable of existing independently of uniforms the company manufactured.

CaseName: Czyzewski V. Jevic Holding Corp.
CaseSummary: A distribution scheme ordered in connection with the dismissal of a Chapter 11 case could not, without the consent of the affected parties, deviate from the basic priority rules that applied under the primary mechanisms the Bankruptcy Code established for final distributions of estate value in business bankruptcies.

CaseName: Sca Hygiene Prods. Aktiebolag V. First Quality Baby Prods., Llc
CaseSummary: Doctrine of laches which precluded unreasonable, prejudicial delay in commencing suit did not apply to patent infringement action for damages since action was filed within statute of limitations for such actions under 35 U.S.C.S. § 286, and judicial application of laches could not override express statutory determination that action was timely.

CaseName: State Farm Fire & Casualty Co. V. United States, Ex Rel Rigsby
CaseSummary: False Claims Act's structure was itself an indication that violating the seal requirement did not mandate dismissal. The insurance company’s arguments to the contrary were unavailing because, inter alia, 31 U.S.C.S. § 3730(b)(2) did not tie the seal requirement to the right to bring the qui tam suit in conditional terms.

CaseName: Life Technologies Corp. V. Promega Corp.
CaseSummary: Phrase “substantial portion” that was used in 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(f)(1) had a quantitative, not qualitative, meaning, and § 271(f)(1) did not govern supply of single component of multicomponent invention which company that was licensed under U.S. Patent No. RE 37,984 manufactured in U.S. and shipped to United Kingdom for use in genetic testing kits.

CaseName: Expressions Hair Design V. Schneiderman
CaseSummary: N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 518, which prohibited merchants from imposing a surcharge based on use of a credit card, was a regulation of speech rather than conduct since the law regulated the manner in which merchants communicated their prices rather than regulating the prices themselves.

CaseName: Matal V. Tam
CaseSummary: PTO violated free speech rights of the lead singer of the rock group, "The Slants," when it refused under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1052(a) to register the band's name as trademark on principal register; § 1052(a) offended bedrock principle of the First Amendment that speech may not be banned on the ground that it expresses an idea that offends other people.

CaseName: Kindred Nursing Centers V. Clark
CaseSummary: U.S. Supreme Court reversed Kentucky Supreme Court's decision invalidating clauses in agreements wife and daughter entered with nursing homes, which required their family members to submit claims to binding arbitration; state supreme court's decision flouted FAA’s command to place arbitration agreements on equal footing with all other contracts.

CaseName: Packingham V. North Carolina
CaseSummary: N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-202.5, which made it a felony for registered sex offenders to access commercial social networking website where an offender knew the site allowed minor children to become members or to create or maintain a personal web page, was unconstitutional because it impermissibly restricted lawful speech in violation of First Amendment.

CaseName: Impression Products V. Lexmark International
CaseSummary: A patent holder could not bring a patent infringement suit against a toner cartridge remanufacturer to enforce the single-use/no-resale provision accompanying its domestic return program cartridges because once sold, the return program cartridges passed outside of the patent monopoly.

CaseName: Advocate Health Care Network V. Stapleton
CaseSummary: Under the best reading of 29 U.S.C.S. § 1002(33)(A) and (C)(i), a plan maintained by a principal-purpose organization qualified as a church plan, regardless of who established it.

CaseName: Honeycutt V. United States
CaseSummary: 21 U.S.C.S. § 853(a)’s limitation of forfeiture to tainted property acquired or used by a defendant, along with 21 U.S.C.S. § 853(a)(1)'s plain text, foreclosed joint and several liability for coconspirators. Forfeiture pursuant to 21 U.S.C.S. § 853(a)(1) was limited to property the defendant himself actually acquired as the result of the crime.

CaseName: Kokesh V. Sec
CaseSummary: Order of disgorgement in an SEC action for violations of securities laws was subject to the five-year statute of limitations under 28 U.S.C.S. § 2462 as a penalty because disgorgement was punitive rather than necessarily compensatory and it was imposed as a consequence of violating public laws as a punitive deterrent.

CaseName: Henson V. Santander Consumer Usa Inc.
CaseSummary: Individuals and entities who regularly purchased debts originated by someone else and then sought to collect those debts for their own account were not debt collectors under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1692a(6) given the text and structure of the word "owed" as used in the FDCPA, as well as the presumption that Congress said what it meant and meant what it said.

CaseName: Trinity Lutheran Church V. Comer, Director, Missouri Department Of Natural Resources
CaseSummary: Missouri Department of Natural Resources violated a church's rights under Free Exercise Clause of First Amendment when it decided that church was ineligible under Mo. Const. art. I, § 7 to participate in a program that offered reimbursement grants to qualifying nonprofit organizations that purchased playground surfaces made from recycled tires.

CaseName: Sandoz Inc. V. Amgen Inc.
CaseSummary: 42 U.S.C.S. § 262(l)(2)(A)’s requirement that an applicant provide the sponsor with its application and manufacturing information was not enforceable by an injunction under federal law given the structure of 35 U.S.C.S. § 271(e)(2)(C), and 42 U.S.C.S. § 262(l)(9)(C) excluded all other remedies, including injunctive relief.

CaseName: District Of Columbia V. Wesby
CaseSummary: Officers had probable cause to arrest the partygoers under the Fourth Amendment because the officers found a group of people who claimed to be having a bachelor party with no bachelor, in a near-empty house, with strippers in the living room and sexual activity in the bedroom, and who fled at the first sign of police.

CaseName: U.s. Bank National Association V. Village At Lakeridge
CaseSummary: Clear error review was properly applied to a bankruptcy court's decision that a purchaser of an insider's bankruptcy claim was not a non-statutory insider for purposes of the cramdown provisions under 11 U.S.C.S. § 1129; determining whether the transaction was arm's-length primarily rested with the bankruptcy court.

CaseName: Merit Management Group, Lp V. Fti Consulting, Inc
CaseSummary: The language of 11 U.S.C.S. § 546(e), the specific context in which that language was used, and the broader statutory structure all supported the conclusion that the relevant transfer for purposes of the § 546(e) safe-harbor inquiry was the overarching transfer that the trustee sought to avoid under one of the substantive avoidance provisions.

CaseName: Cyan V. Beaver County Employees Retirement Fund
CaseSummary: 15 U.S.C.S. § 77v(a)’s except clause did nothing to deprive state courts of their jurisdiction to decide class actions brought under the Securities Act of 1933, 15 U.S.C.S. § 77a et seq., and nothing in the Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998’s purposes and legislative history overcame the clear statutory language.

CaseName: Masterpiece Cakeshop, Ltd. V. Colorado Civil Rights Commission
CaseSummary: Where a state civil rights commission held that a baker violated an anti-discrimination law when he declined to bake a wedding cake for a same sex marriage, the commission violated the First Amendment Free Exercise clause because its treatment of the baker's case displayed clear and impermissible hostility towards his sincere religious beliefs.

CaseName: Rubin V. Islamic Republic Of Iran
CaseSummary: Lower court did not err when it found that U.S. citizens who were wounded in suicide bombings in Jerusalem were not entitled to execute a default judgment they obtained against the Islamic Republic of Iran under 28 U.S.C.S. § 1605A by seizing ancient clay tablets that were owned by Iran but were housed at a university in Chicago, Illinois.

CaseName: Oil States Energy Services, Llc V. Greenes Energy Group, Llc
CaseSummary: Inter partes review under 35 U.S.C.S. §§ 311-319 did not violate U.S. Const. art. III where, inter alia, such review fell squarely within the public-rights doctrine, the review qualified property rights granted by the Patent Act, and nothing in the history or text of the Patent Clause or Article III suggested rejection of such review.

CaseName: Sas Institute Inc. V. Iancu
CaseSummary: Under the plain text of 35 U.S.C.S. § 318(a), the Patent and Trademark Office was required to issue a final written decision with respect to the patentability of any patent claim challenged by the petitioner as the term any meant every, and nothing in 35 U.S.C.S. §§ 314(a) or 318(a) gave the Director the power to decide what claims were at issue.

CaseName: Digital Realty Trust V. Somers
CaseSummary: A former employee was not entitled to protection under the anti-retaliation provision of the Dodd-Frank Act, 15 U.S.C.S. § 78u-6(a)(6), because he was not a whistleblower as defined in the Act since he did not report a securities law violation to the SEC prior to his termination.

CaseName: National Institute Of Family And Life Advocates V. Becerra
CaseSummary: Petitioners who sought to enjoin enforcement of the California Reproductive Freedom, Accountability, Comprehensive Care, and Transparency Act were likely to succeed on the merits of their First Amendment challenge to notice requirements imposed on facilities that provided pregnancy-related services.

CaseName: Minnesota Voters Alliance V. Mansky
CaseSummary: Minn. Stat. § 211B.11, subd. 1 violated First Amendment to the extent it prohibited voters from wearing a political badge, button, or insignia inside a polling place on Election Day because neither statute nor Election Day Policy State developed provided election officials with objective, workable standards which restrained their discretion.

CaseName: Ohio V. American Express Co.
CaseSummary: The anti-steering provisions of a credit-card company's contracts with merchants did not violate 15 U.S.C.S. § 1 of the Sherman Act as it was not shown that the anti-steering provisions had anticompetitive effects; the company's increased merchant fees did not reflect an ability to charge above a competitive price.

CaseName: Lozman V. City Of Riviera Beach, Florida
CaseSummary: Where petitioner was arrested at a city council meeting for allegedly violating its rules of procedure and failing to leave the podium when ordered to do so, and claimed that arrest was in retaliation for past speech in violation of his First Amendment rights, the fact that arrest was made with probable cause did not bar his retaliation claim.

CaseName: Westerngeco Llc V. Ion Geophysical Corp.
CaseSummary: Court of Appeals for Federal Circuit erred when it found that LLC that owned patents for system used to survey ocean floor was not allowed under Patent Act to recover lost foreign profits from company that manufactured components for competing system in U.S., which it shipped abroad to companies that combined components to create competing system.

CaseName: South Dakota V. Wayfair
CaseSummary: State of South Dakota was not prohibited under the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution from enacting legislation which required remote sellers to collect and remit sales tax on goods and services sold to buyers for delivery in South Dakota, even though the business that made the sale did not have a physical presence in the State.

CaseName: Lamar, Archer & Cofrin V. Appling
CaseSummary: Debtor's statements regarding his tax refund could qualify as "statements respecting the debtor's financial condition" under 11 U.S.C.S. § 523(a)(2)(B), so that the debt was not barred from discharge because the statements were not in writing; a statement about a single asset could be a statement respecting the debtor's financial condition.

CaseName: Sveen V. Melin
CaseSummary: Contracts Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 1, did not prevent a revocation-on-divorce law, Minn. Stat. § 524.2-804, subd. 1 (2016), from applying to a preexisting beneficiary designation because the law did not substantially impair preexisting contractual arrangements, particularly as the law was designed to reflect a policyholder's intent.

CaseName: Weyerhaeuser Company V. U.s. Fish And Wildlife Service
CaseSummary: Supreme Court vacated court of appeals' judgment upholding Fish and Wildlife Service's decision to designate 1,544-acre site in Louisiana as critical habitat for dusky gopher frog because, inter alia, dusky gopher frog no longer lived in designated area and court had rejected suggestion that "critical habitat" contained habitability requirement.

CaseName: Henry Schein Inc. V. Archer And White Sales Inc.
CaseSummary: When parties had agreed that an arbitrator should decide the gateway question of arbitrability, the matter had to be decided by the arbitrator, and a "wholly groundless" exception to arbitration was not available under the FAA to enable courts to block transferring such a dispute to arbitration.

CaseName: Sturgeon V. Frost
CaseSummary: Under 16 U.S.C.S. § 3103(c), state, Native, and private lands could be regulated only as they could have been before enactment of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act unless and until bought by the federal government. The Nation River was not public land under the Act, and National Park Service hovercraft regulations did not apply.

CaseName: Republic Of Sudan V. Harrison
CaseSummary: 28 U.S.C.S. § 1608(a)(3) was not satisfied when a service packet that named the foreign minister was mailed to the foreign state’s embassy in the United States. Rather, the most natural reading of the language in § 1608(a)(3) was that service had to be mailed directly to the foreign minister’s office in the foreign state.

CaseName: Apple Inc. V. Pepper
CaseSummary: Cellphone owners were proper plaintiffs for antitrust suit alleging that unlawful use of monopoly power to force owners to pay higher prices for applications (hereinafter, apps), because, under Illinois Brick, owners were direct purchasers who might have sued corporation for alleged monopolization as owners bought apps directly from corporation.

CaseName: Fourth Estate Public Benefit Corp. V. Wall-street.com
CaseSummary: Court held that registration of copyright occurred in accordance with 17 U.S.C.S. § 411(a), and copyright claimant could commence a copyright infringement suit, when Copyright Office registered a copyright. Upon registration of the copyright, however, copyright owner could recover for infringement that occurred both before and after registration.

CaseName: Lorenzo V. Securities And Exchange Commission
CaseSummary: By sending e-mails he understood to contain material untruths, a broker-dealer employed a device, scheme, and artifice to defraud within the meaning of SEC Rule 10b-5(a), 17 C.F.R. § 240.10b-5, and 15 U.S.C.S. § 77q(a)(1), even though he sent the e-mails at the direction of his client, who supplied the content and “approved” the messages.

CaseName: Nieves V. Bartlett
CaseSummary: Respondent’s retaliatory arrest claim against two police officers could not succeed because they had probable cause to arrest him. The existence of probable cause to arrest respondent defeated his First Amendment claim as a matter of law.

CaseName: Helsinn Healthcare S.a. V. Teva Pharmaceuticals Usa Inc.
CaseSummary: U.S. Court of Appeals for Federal Circuit properly found that Swiss company was prohibited by "on sale" bar in 35 U.S.C.S. § 102(a)(1) from obtaining U.S. patent on a drug that treated chemotherapy-induced nausea because it entered into agreements with Minnesota company to sell its drug in U.S. more than one year before it applied for U.S. patent.

CaseName: Franchise Tax Board Of California V. Hyatt
CaseSummary: Nevada v. Hall, wherein a taxpayer prevailed in a state court suit against a state franchise tax board, was overruled because States retained sovereign immunity from private suits in the courts of other States, and stare decisis did not compel continued adherence to it as it was an outlier in U.S. Supreme Court sovereign immunity jurisprudence.

CaseName: Obduskey V. Mccarthy & Holthus Llp
CaseSummary: The last sentence of 15 U.S.C.S. § 1692a(6) did (with its 15 U.S.C.S. § 1692f(6) exception) place those whose principal purpose was the enforcement of security interests outside the scope of the primary debt collector definition, §1692a(6), where the business was engaged in no more than nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings.

CaseName: Thacker V. Tennessee Valley Authority
CaseSummary: In a suit wherein petitioner alleged that TVA had failed to exercise reasonable care in assembling and installing power lines and in warning boaters like him of the hazards it created, Supreme Court held that waiver of sovereign immunity in TVA’s sue-and-be-sued clause was not subject to a discretionary function exception, of the kind in the FTCA.

CaseName: Return Mail Inc. V. U.s. Postal Service
CaseSummary: In a case in which the United States Postal Service sought covered-business-method review of a patent holder’s patent, which claimed a method for processing undeliverable mail, the Supreme Court held that a federal agency is not a “person” who may petition for post-issuance review under the Leahy-Smith America Invents Act of 2011

CaseName: Rimini Street Inc. V. Oracle Usa Inc.
CaseSummary: The Copyright Act did not explicitly authorize the award of litigation expenses beyond the six categories specified in 28 U.S.C.S. §§ 1821 and 1920. And §§ 1821 and 1920 in turn did not authorize an award for expenses such as expert witness fees, e-discovery expenses, and jury consultant fees.

CaseName: Mission Product Holdings Inc. V. Tempnology, Llc
CaseSummary: Debtor's rejection of trademark licensing agreement could not revoke license and did not deprive licensee of its rights to use trademark because, under 11 U.S.C.S. § 365, debtor’s rejection of an executory contract in bankruptcy had the same effect as breach outside bankruptcy. Such an act could not rescind rights that contract previously granted.

CaseName: Manhattan Community Access Corp. V. Halleck
CaseSummary: Under the state-action doctrine, the operation of public access channels on a cable system was not a traditional, exclusive public function, and thus, a private entity that opened its property for speech by others was not thereby transformed into a state actor and therefore not subject to First Amendment constraints on its editorial discretion.

CaseName: American Legion V. American Humanist Association
CaseSummary: The Bladensburg Peace Cross did not violate the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment because, although the cross was a preeminent Christian symbol, its use in the Bladensburg memorial had a special significance in commemorating World War I. The cross became a symbol of the sacrifice made by the American soldiers killed in the war.

CaseName: Tennessee Wine & Spirits Retailers Association V. Thomas
CaseSummary: Since the effect of a 2-year residency requirement for retail license applicants was to protect Tennessee Wine and Spirits Retailers Association members from out-of-state competition and had little relation to public health and safety, Tenn. Code Ann. § 57-3-204(b)(2)(A) violated the Commerce Clause and was not saved by U.S. Const. amend. 21, § 2.

CaseName: The Dutra Group V. Batterton
CaseSummary: Because there was no historical basis for allowing punitive damages in unseaworthiness actions, and in order to promote uniformity with the way courts had applied parallel statutory causes of action, punitive damages remained unavailable in unseaworthiness actions.

CaseName: Iancu V. Brunetti
CaseSummary: Denial of trademark registration under the Lanham Act for a mark that was described as the equivalent of profanity violated the First Amendment because the "immoral or scandalous" bar under 15 U.S.C.S. § 1052(a) unconstitutionally discriminated on the basis of viewpoint.

CaseName: Emulex Corp. V. Varjabedian
North Carolina Department Of Revenue V. The Kimberley Rice Kaestner 1992 Family Trust
CaseSummary: The residence of the trust beneficiaries in North Carolina alone did not supply the minimum connection necessary to sustain the State’s income tax under the Due Process Clause where the beneficiaries received no income from the trust, had no right to demand trust income, and could not count on receiving any income in the future.

CaseName: Taggart V. Lorenzen
CaseSummary: In a case in which petitioner sought civil contempt sanctions against respondents for collecting attorney fees in violation of bankruptcy court's discharge order, Supreme Court held that a court may hold creditor in civil contempt for violating a discharge order if there was no fair ground of doubt as to whether the order barred creditor’s conduct.
